You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK must set up a commission to investigate atrocities committed during the “long shadow of the British Empire”, MPs have said.In the wake of global protests at the death of George Floyd, the Liberal Democrats have proposed investigating Britain’s imperial record, to establish the extent of human rights abuses and wrongdoing.The plan includes an overhaul of the school curriculum to broaden teaching of black history and the creation of citizen’s assemblies to debate memorials to the UK’s imperial legacy. The idea could reignite the furore which erupted in the UK after the death of Mr Floyd - which saw the statue of slave trader Edward Colston toppled and cast into Bristol’s harbour. The Black Lives Matter protests, sparked by Mr Floyd’s death at the hands of a white police officer, prompted fresh recriminations about the UK’s colonial past, including monuments to people linked with the slave trade.  A statue of slaveholder Robert Milligan was removed from London’s Docklands in June, and Mayor Sadiq Khan announced a review of all statues and street names linked to the slave trade in London.Tensions flared at demonstrations in London, with a statue of Winston Churchill daubed with graffiti. Lib Dem equalities spokesperson Christine Jardine, who will move the motion at the party’s autumn conference, said: “Racial justice cannot wait. The UK has never properly addressed the long shadow of the British Empire nor done anywhere near enough to eradicate systemic racism in our society and our institutions. We must fill the gaps in our national narrative. “A commission would play a vital role in uncovering historic injustice and abuse, to truly lay bare the legacy of the Empire. Citizens’ Assemblies will empower communities to take charge of how that history is memorialised and contextualised to build a more inclusive country.

title: what new dominic cummings allegations
story: NewsWhat new Dominic Cummings allegations mean and why they matter - timelineBoris Johnsons senior aide faces fresh questions about his lockdown trip after a new story in the Daily Mirror. Heres what the new allegations are, why they matter, and a timeline piecing the case togetherShareByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political EditorDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsDominic Cummings originally came under fire for travelling  miles during coronavirus lockdown" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDominic Cummings faces calls to produce evidence proving he didnapost make a second lockdown trip after a new story by the Daily Mirror. Our front page today reports the account of witnesses who believe they saw the PMaposs top aide near Durham on the morning April .That is almost a week after he ed to London. Yet Mr Cummings categorically denies he made a second trip up north, and says he has evidence to prove it. Todayaposs story has come to light after two of the alleged witnesses, Clare Edwards, , and her husband Dave, complained to the Independent Office for Police Conduct. Clare believes her allegation that she saw Mr Cummings on April  was not taken seriously enough by officers. Given itaposs months now since the original story, it can be hard to grasp what this all means, and why it matters. So here is an explainer.What did Dominic Cummings do  The Tory adviser drove  miles with his we, who had Covid- symptoms, and son to self-isolate at his family farm near Durham on March  at the height of the lockdown. The next morning Mr Cummings himself fell ill, and the family proceeded to stay for two weeks, including a night when his son ended up in hospital, although he tested negative. During their stay, the family went to Barnard Castle,  miles away, on April , which Mr Cummings later claimed was to test his eyesight before the drive to London the next day. Mr Cummings admitted the trip but claimed he had not broken the rules. That is despite the rules at the time clearly banning non-essential travel, or leaving your home at allyou or a member of your household had symptoms. He claimed he was exempt from these rules because he needed to seek childcare for his son, in case he fell too ill to care for him. But he admitted he did not, in the end, need childcare. He ed to London on April .  What did police do  Durham Police investigated, and concluded on May  that there might have been a minor breach of the Regulations that would have warranted police intervention. However, the force added: Durham Constabulary view this as minor because there was no apparent breach of social distancing. Had a Durham Constabulary police officer stopped Mr Cummings driving to or from Barnard Castle, the officer would have spoken to him, and, having established the facts, likely advised Mr Cummings toto the address in Durham, providing advice on the dangers of travelling during the pandemic crisis. Had this advice been accepted by Mr Cummings, no enforcement action would have been taken. They also took witness statements and a photograph from the Edwardses on May , after being contacted by the couple. In their statement on May  they concluded there was insufficient evidence to investigate further.  What are new witnesses saying  A man got in touch with the Mirror on April , claiming he saw Mr Cummings with a female companion in Houghall Woods at . that morning. But in a press conference in the No garden in May, Mr Cummings denied this claim – saying: Photos and data on my phone prove this to be . Since then, three other people who claim to have seen Mr Cummings on April  have come forward.Clare Edwards, , said she is “% certain” she saw Boris Johnson ’s chief adviser while walking in Houghall Woods near Durham on the morning of Sunday, April . Her husband Dave claims to have seen Mr Cummings too. Clare and Dave have now comp­lained to the Independent Office for Police Conduct, claiming Durham police did not properly investigate their allegations about Mr Cummings. Another new witness claims to have seen Mr Cummings and a female companion walking between the beauty spot and the family home that morning between . and .. Another person then said they think they saw Mr Cummings on Hampstead Heath in North London that afternoon, four hours later at .pm. A test-drive of the route on a quiet Sunday after lockdown took three hours and  minutes.  How is this dferent to what we knew already  It is all about the date. The people who have spoken to the Mirror believe they saw Mr Cummings near Durham on April . That is almost a week after Mr Cummings ed to London from his two-week stay with his family. If Mr Cummings was in Durham on the morning of April , which he has previously denied, it would mean he made a second trip during lockdown. And that he misled both the PM - who spent six hours discussing the matter with him - and the public.  Why does it matter  Firstly, Dominic Cummings categorically denied that he had made a second trip to Durham during lockdown. So the claims suggest that either the witnesses were mistaken, or that Mr Cummings did make a second trip but said otherwise. Secondly, Mr Cummings said he had evidence to prove he did not make a second trip to Durham. Boris Johnson also suggested he had seen this evidence, saying:it pleases you I will say yes, I did. So the new claims add pressure on Mr Cummings or Downing Street to say what this evidence was. Thirdly, Mr Cummings gave a detailed -controversial - reasoning for travelling up north at the end of March. If he had travelled up north a second time, which he denies, this reasoning would be discredited. And fourthly, the law still banned leaving oneaposs home without reasonable excuse on April . A second trip would raise questions about whether this was followed.  What happens now  Labour have now demanded Dominic Cummings produce the evidence to prove he did not make a second trip to the north east during lockdown.Deputy leader Angela Rayner said: The public have a right to know whether the Prime Minister’s chief advisor made a second lockdown-breaching trip to Durham, and it is surely therefore only right that this evidence is produced. If Dominic Cummings was in London during both the morning and afternoon of the th April, and not in Durham as has been alleged, I’m sure that he the Prime Minister will welcome this opportunity to set the record straight.Former North West prosecutor Nazir Afzal, whose brother died of coronavirus, has launched his own appeal for evidence after accusing the police forces who investigated the case of ”closing ranks”.He said today: “Mr Cummings stated that he was not in Durham at any time on the th, he and these witnesses cannot both be right. “The failure of the police to investigate remains very disappointing given the public interest and concern.” The Met Police is also coming under pressure to investigate the allegations from, among others, the chair of Londonaposs Police and Crime Committee. But a No spokesman said yesterday: “Durham Constabulary have made clear they are not taking any further action against Mr Cummings and that by locating himself at his father’s premises he did not breach the regulations. “The Prime Minister has said he believes Mr Cummings behaved reasonably and he considers the matter closed.” Durham Constabulary said: “As outlined in our statement of May , [we] carried out an investigation into this matter led by a senior detective and found insufficient evidence to support the allegation.” Timeline of events Monday  March: Prime Minister Boris Johnson advises everyone in the UK to stop non-essential contact with others and to stop all unnecessary travel.Monday  March: In an evening TV address, the PM announces a UK-wide lockdown - effective immediately - to contain the spread of the virus. The public are instructed that they must stay at home from that evening, except for four very limited purposes - shopping for necessities, one form of exercise per day, any medical need, and travelling to and from workneeded. Public gatherings of more than two people, unless from the same household or under an exception, are banned effective immediately. Thursday  March: The lockdown restrictions that the PM launched on  March formally take force in law at pm, with £ fines for first-time offenders who break the rules. The three-day lag is due to the need to pass legislation through Parliament.Friday  March: Dominic Cummings is spotted running out of No to rush home to his we, who is ill with coronavirus symptoms. The family travel up to his parents’ home near Durham that weekend. Cummings later falls ill with the virus, but they do not need childcare for their four-year-old son as his we recovers. Tuesday  March: Durham Police have said they were “made aware” that the PM’s top aide was in the area and spoke to his father, although it is unclear whether they approached him or the other way round.Sunday  April: Cummings is seen standing outside the family property with a little boy and Abba blasting out on the radio. Downing Street declines to comment.Sunday  April: The family are seen at Barnard Castle,  miles away, by retired chemistry teacher Robin Lees on a trip which Cummings later claimed was to test his eyesight before the long drive back to London. It was also Cummings’ we’s birthday.Monday  April: Cummings travels back to London and the following day is seen at Downing Street.Friday  April: Cummings is among senior aides who visit the Prime Minister at Chequers.Sunday  April .am – witnesses claim they spot Dominic Cummings looking at bluebells in Houghall Woods. Downing Street says that Cummings is in London.am – Clare and David Edwards claim they see him with a group of people by the side of a path in the woods..-.am – a fourth witness alleges that the Prime Minister’s top aide walks past them between the woods and his parents’ home..pm – a member of the public claims that they see Cummings and his family on Hampstead Heath, North London. Cummings has denied being the person seeen. Thursday  April: We Mary Wakefield writes about the family’s self-isolation in the Spectator magazine - and talks of emerging from quarantine  into the almost comical uncertainty of London lockdown.Sunday  May:Boris Johnson addresses the nation to confirm he will ease lockdown - but people in England can only meet one person from another household, in public, and not stay overnight.Friday  May: The Mirror and thebreak the story that Dominic Cummings made a trip to Durham during lockdown. No  sources claim he had not broken the rules because he and his we had needed his parents to look after their son while they were ill.Monday  May: Dominic Cummings gives an extraordinary press conference in the No garden. He says the trip to Barnard Castle was to test his eyesight, and admits he went back into  Downing Street in person after visiting his sick we Mary on March . However, he denies making a second trip up north after hison April , saying: Photos and data on my phone prove this to be .

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA car plunged off a clf and landed near to sunbathers on a popular tourist beach. Shocked beach-goers fled in panic as the black vehicle fell ft directly onto a tent at the Mawgan Porth, near Newquay, Cornwall. Thankfully no-one on the beach was hurt despite crowds of people sitting nearby. Dramatic pictures show the incident which left the driver suffering minor injuries. Emergency services rushed to the scene shortly before .pm on Thursday, August . Padstow Coastguard said that the reason the car left the road is still unknown. A spokesperson said: We were requested to assist Newquay Coastguard, alongside South Western Ambulance NHS Service Trust, Cornwall Fire and Rescue Service and Devon and Cornwall Police, with a car that had landed on the beach. Initial reports of the vehicle driving off a clf and landing on a beach tent were confirmed, however it had left the B road, and dropped approximately ft, thankfully onto what was at the time, an empty beach tent. With no other casualties other than minor injuries on the driver only, Padstow team were then stood down. Two team members had already arrived on scene, and remained, assisting the remaining emergency services to right the car back onto its wheels, and remove it from the beach.  The cause of the vehicle to leave the road is not known, but it was slow enough not to activate the on board airbags. With no medical, safety or pollution concerns, the emergency services removed ious pieces of debris from the incident, and were able to depart the scene as requested. Excellent multi service operations, and an extraordinarily lucky outcome for the driver and beachgoers.

The plane taking  passengers to Manchester took off just  metres from the end of the runway at Lisbon Airport in Portugal on September , . The pilots realised something was wrong as they were thundering down the runway and saw red and white flashing lights indicating they had m left. The Airbus A- passed over the end of the runway at a height of ft. An Air Accidents Investigation Branch report said there were “several obstructions beyond the runway that could have caused signicant damage to the aircraft and its occupants”. The two pilots had used tablet computers to work out the acceleration needed to get airborne. They meant to input that they were starting their take-off from ,m up the two-and-a-half mile runway at the point of an intersecting taxiway called S. But they wrongly inputted that they were starting from taxiway S at the start of the runway. The autopilot assumed they had an extra ,m to take off, and reduced their initial speed to compensate.

Each of the beds are still neatly made up, asthey are waiting to be slept in once more. While the windows are boarded there are signs of a long-forgotten le all over the eerie abandoned home. In a nursery, a crowd of stuffed animals have been lovingly placed in a crib, no longer played with and waiting to be picked up once more. Even the lights have been left on asthe former owners plan toand pick up their old le where they left off. Family snaps line the mantel piece as dried flowers take up pride of place in the fire place that hasnapost known heat for more than  years. Shelves and dressers are filled with knick knacks and the huge comfy sofas havenapost been sat on for more than a decade and now simply gather dust. Paintings hang on the walls of the bedrooms while several of the ornate beds are decorated with bright throws, useful only now for the insects and mice who have made the huge house their home. Meanwhile, in the utility room, an indoor watering can waits by the sink to water long dead plants. Cooking utensils still hang on the kitchen wall, which comes complete with a huge cooker unused for family meals for years. Clothes are still folded neatly in drawers with no attempt made to pack them, while a stunning wooden piano and a drum kit have remained unplayed since . A bike stands ready to be ridden in the hallway, while a bathroom is draped over the side of the bath, ready for whoever should need it next. Even the electric toothbrush, propped up next to a sink, still has battery le in it. In the sun-dappled conservatory a single candle has drouped under the weight of the constant sunlight. One of the most heartbreaking finds, discovered by urban explorer, Freaky D, is handwritten note, penned by children, left in drawers and on shelves in the house. He said: The house is filled with letters between family members and friends, photographs from celebrations, crafts made by the children and countless other items that make it a very typical family home. Notes left out from small children in scrawled handwriting with heartfelt love letters to their parents really give this abandoned home character - and a lot of emotion. Itaposs unclear why the mansion was abandoned so suddenly and after lying empty for so long it has been targeted by vandals. Ivy now grows over the windows that havenapost been boarded up, giving the whole house an eerie glow. Freaky D said: The whole house appears like the family had just vanished without a trace, a family home full of le had, in the blink of an eye, been frozen in time. I really hope this property remains hidden from people who wish to disrupt this amazing building. According to Freaky D, the house was used as a rectory for many years and the present building has been in place since approximately . The Rectory served a small village which had very prominent links with the mining industry.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA new exhibition centre is letting electric car owners pay for parking with electricity as manufacturers look at ways of utilising zero emission vehicles outside of driving. The Nissan Pavilion is a ,-square-metre, zero-emission centre fitted with solar  and supplied with renewable hydroelectric power. And in a global first, electric vehicle drivers will be able to discharge power from their caraposs battery pack to pay for parking when they visit. The process at the complex in Yokohama, Japan, has been designed to showcase the Nissan LEAF electric caraposs aposvehicle to gridaposcharging capability, and gives a glimpse at how British companies will be able to save money from their fleets of electric cars. The LEAF, which is built at Nissanaposs Sunderland plant as well as in Japan, has bi-directional charging that allows power to be pulled from its battery as well as be supplied to it. On this occasion, the Nissan Pavilion is absorbing electricity from the Nissan as a aposparking feeapos, but the LEAF family hatchback can also be used to supply energy to bricks and mortar closer to home. It is estimated the kWh battery from a Nissan LEAF can power the average UK home for a week. Makoto Uchida, Nissan CEO, said: The Pavilion is a place where customers can see, feel, and be inspired by our near-future vision for society and mobility. As the world shts to electric mobility, EVs will be integrated into society in ways that go beyond just transportation. The exhibition centre also has a cafe which operates on power supplied by the LEAF electric cars and solar energy. In the UK, Nissan has partnered with energy provider E.ON to explore the use of vehicle-to-grid charging.The two companies have this week successfully installed  VGchargers at the car manufactureraposs European Technical Centre in Cranfield, Bedfordshire. It demonstrates how storing and sharing electricity in fleet vehiclesapos batteries can generate additional revenue for participating companies as well as supporting the power grid. The project, co-funded by Innovate UK, allows energy stored in car batteries to be sold back to the grid when demand for power is high.

To fill the time, many people have taken up new hobbies and some families have said their new shared interests have brought them closer together - and they plan to continue them going forward. As the governmentaposs restrictions ease, the Very Big Family Le Survey with Very has looked back at how we all spent the strictest months of lockdown and how people view the “new normal”.Both kids and their parents have the opportunity to do new things, with  per cent of mums and dads with teenage kids saying theyaposve tried something for the first time or more often than normal. Cooking and baking is the most popular aposnewapos activity, with  per cent of parents with teenagers and  per cent of people with younger kids surveyed listing it. Gardening and exercise were next up on the list in both groups. Meanwhile, their kids have also enjoyed cooking and baking, at  per cent, while  per cent have tried their hand at gardening. Arts and crafts and growing their own fruit and veg also made the top five.Interestingly, the exclusive Daily Mirror and Very survey showed that gardening was far lower down the list for kids younger than , with exercise in second place after cooking and baking.Boys were more likely to have spent more time playing a musical instrument and doing DIY. And for many, the group activities have brought them together as a family. Describing the positives of lockdown, one parent wrote: Being able to help more with the kids home schooling as normally I am in work. Building a veg garden and growing our own veg has been a fun thing for all of us.  And I feel we have all grown closer as a family. Meanwhile, other families used the opportunity to exercise and to improve their fitness. Some even opted to do this all together, either through group work outs or by making it a competition. One parent said: Getting myself fitter by running more on my treadmill. The rest of family doing it as well, so we are fitter as a family physically and mentally. Some made the most of their one trip out of the house for exercise by going out for a walk with loved ones. One wrote: Going for a walk with my daughter and spotting all the wildle and breathing cleaner air. Another added: Going out for walks and discovering areas around where I live that I never knew were there. While everyone has obviously faced their own challenges in lockdown, some people have found itaposs also brought some advantages, Veryaposs research found. Parents of younger kids are more likely to have found the lockdown fun compared to those with teenage children, but an incredible amount say the restrictions have brought them closer as a family.

story: NewsMiracle baby born inside out with % chance of survival finally leaves hospitalMax Staines, now four, was born with his stomach, liver and bowels on the outside of his body - a rare condition called gastroschisis - with his mother, Lauren, even being advised to abort himShareByHollie Bone:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsMax was given just a % chance of survival when he was born " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . Max Staines, now four, was born with his stomach, liver and bowels on the outside of his body - a rare condition called gastroschisis. Mum Lauren, , was given the diagnosis of her unborn baby at her  week scan, with medics warning her the chances of Max surviving were very low. They even offered Lauren the chance to abort her unborn child. But the former cabin crew member refused, and Max defied doctors predictions at every turn, finally getting discharged from St George’s Hospital in central London in June. Max underwent four years of regular appointments since le-saving surgery at birth. Lauren, from Hook, Hants, said today: “Every single day I look at him and think you are my miracle. “Everybody calls him my ‘miracle baby’ but at the same time we worked bloody hard to get him through this and he fought so hard as well. “I look back at pictures and realise how far we have come from being absolutely terried of being a single mum and worrying that I was going to leave hospital without a baby at all to being as happy as we are now. “When we were told that he was going to be discharged, it was the perfect piece of the puzzle towards our happy ending.” At  weeks pregnant in January , doctors confirmed both Max’s liver and bowels were outside of his body, but were unable to determine how damaged they would be from fluid in the amniotic sack until he was born.  Despite the devastating odds, Lauren enjoyed a successful pregnancy with no cramps, sickness or tiredness, but was growing increasingly concerned that with every week that passed, Max’s organs were becoming more damaged. Expert surgeons at St George’s had put together a full birth plan, but in April that year, the expectant mum was thrown into action when she realised her usually active baby hadn’t moved or kicked all day and decided to go to the local hospital to check nothing untoward was happening. Max’s heart rate had dropped and doctors decided to perform an emergency c-section, transferring the newborn straight to St George’s for a six-hour operation to package his exposed stomach, liver and bowels, back inside his body. Mum of one, Lauren, added: “When he was born the nurse asked meI wanted to look at him and I hesitated. “She said ‘right too late’ he’s going to have to go and he was transferred to St George’s before I’d even seen him. “I couldn’t go with him because they wanted me to be able to stand up on my own before I was transferred as well.  “I didn’t get to meet him for nine hours after he was born, and when I got to St George’s his surgeon said ‘it’s a lot worse than we had anticipated’. “But when he came back out after the operation, he had a huge smile on his face and looked at me and said ‘we managed to do a full closure’.” After the emergency surgery, Max had to be fitted with a long line to give his body the nutrients he wouldn’t be able to get until his stomach could digest food, and doctors had to drain the remaining fluid from around his organs with an NG tube. But despite predictions he would need to stay in hospital for six months, the defiant tot made rapid progression, and within three weeks was on his mum’s milk and was able to be sent home. Since then Max has been under the close watch of medics at St George’s with regular appointments and talks of fitting him with a colostomy bag to manage the fact he was unable to tell when he needed the toilet due to his shortened bowel.  But in another miraculous turn, the youngster suddenly realised his own toilet cues in January this year and was able to go into ‘big boy pants’ overnight. Recalling her pregnancy, Lauren said: “We’d been in a relationship for a couple of years but Max’s dad didnapost want to have a baby so I decided to go ahead with the pregnancy on my own. “When I went for my first ultrasound scan at  weeks, the lady was looking at the screen for ages and then said she wanted to get someone to check something. “I could see from on the look on her face that something was wrong. “When she came back, they told me that they believed his organs were on the outside of his body, that it was very rare and they didn’t really know what they were looking at so they referred me to another hospital.

Crathie Kirk - a regular place of worship for the royal family when they are in residence at the estate - is among the places subject to rules allowing communal prayer for a maximum of  people, with two-metre distancing in place. A Buckingham Palace spokesman previously said arrangements for the Queenaposs stay in Scotland will be in line with the relevant guidelines and advice. They were driven from Windsor to RAF Northolt in London earlier this week, where they then boarded a plane heading to the ,-acre Aberdeenshire estate, where they are expected to stay until at least September. They will be joined by whataposs been dubbed their aposBalmoral Bubbleapos, a small team of key staff who will look after them during their stay.It includes master of the household Vice-Admiral Tony Johnstone-Burt, the Queenaposs private secretary Sir Edward Young and Paul Whybrew and William Henderson, her pages. story: NewsRSPCA explains whether giving your dogs ice cubes in the hot weather is safeThe RSPCA has given us some advice on how to cool down your pets in the heatwaveShareByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience WriterRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  AUG NewsDogs can suffer from heatstroke within minutes " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWith temperatures soaring, itaposs important to keep your pets feeling cool and comfortable.In the hot weather, your dogs can suffer from heatstroke within minutes. It occurs when a dog cannot reduce its own body temperature - and it can be deadly.So itaposs vital that you avoid going for walks during hotter periods, keep your pets hydrated and in the shade when sitting outside. But over the years, there has been a lot of speculation as to whether itaposs safe to give your dogs ice cubes in a heatwave. And with so much information available, itaposs hard to know what you can and canapost trust. So we asked the experts at the RSPCA to debunk the issue. Are we allowed to give our dogs ice cubes during a heatwave  The answer is yes, and itaposs recommended. Over the years, a number of pets owners have been cautious not to give their dogs ice cube, in fear that their belly will bloat - this is extremely dangerous in larger dogs especially. But giving ice and other frozen goodies to dogs is safe, and can help to keep their temperatures down.   A spokesman for the animal rescue charity said: “The RSPCA advises freezing a dogaposs water bowl or kong before putting water or fresh treats inside .  We also advise putting ice cubes into your petaposs water or making frozen treats to help cool them down.  You could try adding a meat stock like chicken or beef to your ice cubes too. But some vets fear that giving your dogs ice could lead to tooth damage.Dr. Susan C. Nelson, a clinical professor at the Veterinary Health Center at Kansas State University said to  PetMD  : The larger and harder the cube, the higher the chance of this occurring.Offering dogs smaller cubes or even ice shavings can help prevent this problem.

Lebanon’s President Michel Aoun said: “There is a possibility of a rocket or bomb or other act.’“ The blast, which flattened much of Beirut’s port, was caused when a fire set off a ,-ton pile of ammonium nitrate in a warehouse. But shipping company Portico wants permission to store up to , tons in ­Portsmouth, Hants. The firm insists the plan is safe. But there are fears over the risk posed by the chemical, used in ­fertiliser. Terror group Hezbollah has previously threatened to use it as a weapon and MI foiled a plot in London five years ago.Last year Hezbollah chief Hassan Nasrallah claimed he was storing the substance in Haa, Israel, adding: “A few missiles hit the tanks [and] tens ofthousands will be killed.”Haras Rafiq, who has sat on ious government taskforces combating extremism and terrorism, said of Nasrallah’s grim boast: “In that video, he states it wouldn’t take much to turn that stored chemical into deadly bombs.  We certainly need to be more vigilant when looking at Hezbollah and how it operates globally.” Three tons of ammonium nitrate were found in four London properties in . A man in his s was arrested but later released. Meanwhile, Portico defended its ­Portsmouth plan, saying: “These goods are handled on a regular basis in ports and held in larger quantities in agricultural businesses.  Strict inspections are in place, our licence is for the smaller, lower risk amount.” Portsmouth City Council leader Gerald Vernon-Jackson added: “Every port in the country imports fertiliser. It will be trucked out, it won’t sit around.”

title: voice mirror dominic cummings free
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Dominic Cummings has a free pass that symbolises the Prime Ministers arroganceBoris Johnson’s regime has further undermined its fragile trust by sticking up two fingers at people over the behaviour of privileged No adviser Dominic Cummings who broke the lockdown rulesShareByVoice of the Mirror:,  AUG NewsopinionDominic Cummings " %, rgba, rgba, url"What is really going on in politics  Get our daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDowning Street’s contempt for the British public is corrosive. Boris Johnson’s regime has further undermined its fragile trust by sticking up two fingers at people over the behaviour of privileged No adviser Dominic Cummings. In defying the growing clamour to respond to witnesses insisting they saw Cummings on a second lockdown-breaking visit to County Durham, suspicions understandably rise about what the Government has to hide. The head of Westminster’s all-party Public Accounts Committee, Meg Hillier, has asked to “have the truth out in the open”. It is a legitimate appeal for transparency that a Downing Street confident of its position would be falling over itself to meet. Johnson giving Cummings a free pass symbolised the arrogance of a Prime Minister who behaves asrules are for the little people. If Cummings has evidence that he is not a serial offender, let him publish or be damned. Hard Prest PRESTON in Lancashire is the latest town to be put under local lockdown – worrying evidence that this virus is not beaten. This crisis could go either way, with the Office for National Statistics suggesting the number of infections in England may be levelling off – while experts on the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies recently warned “it does not have confidence” that the vital R reproduction rate is below one in England.  Imposing local restrictions inconveniences families but the measures are necessary. It’s better to lock down areas where the virus surges now than risk a second shutdown of the entire country in the coming winter.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA fugitive on the run for  years has been caught by the same police officer he was jailed for shooting. Luis Archuleta, , escaped a Colorado jail in  where he was serving time for shooting and wounding Daril Cinquanta in Denver three years earlier. Mr Cinquanta, , retired in  but lived by the mantra “you can run, but you can’t hide”, and never forgot about Archuleta. He kept in contact with “bad guys”, askingthey knew where the fugitive was. He drew a blank until June  when he received a mystery tip-off – leading to the FBI capturing one their “most wanted”.  Mr Cinquanta, who was shot once in the stomach, said tracking Archuleta became “like a hobby”. He said: “I have never given up on him. It just shows you, persistence does pay off. “I was cold calling people, bad guys, I went to their homes and most of the reception was not warm. I’m not real popular with bad guys’ families.” He said the caller handed Archuleta to him “on a platter”, saying: “I’ve thought about it, I’m going to tell you where he’s at.”  Cinquanta added: “He’s been wanted  years, I’ve been working on him  years and I found him. It feels wonderful. “I’ve gotten calls from all over from policemen who think it’s phenomenal.” Recalling the shooting, he said: “He looked like a bad actor. I confronted him. He put his arm back and was pulling a gun. I lost that battle. In those days, we didn’t have bulletproof vests and radios did not come out of our cars, so I had to crawl to the car to call for help.”

title: alliance for independences bid for a holyrood super majority dubbed cynical
story: A bid by a former SNP MSP to maximise the independence vote at Holyrood has been dealt a serious blow after the Greens refused to co-operate with the controversial plan.Green co-convener Patrick Harvie has rejected Dave Thomson’s Alliance for Independence , describing it as a “cynical” attempt to “game” the Holyrood system.Mr Harvie also said he was not inclined to work with Mr Thomson, who was an SNP MSP for almost a decade, because he had voted against same-sex marriage.Mr Thompson, a former MSP for Skye Lochaber and Badenoch, quit the SNP after -years’ membership to form the AFI, which aims to capture up to  Holyrood list seats by acting as an umbrella group for the smaller Yes-supporting parties outside the SNP.A key part of his strategy is to get the independence-backing Greens, Tommy Sheridan’s Solidarity party, the Scottish Socialist Partyand the newly formed Independence for Scotlandparty to join his alliance.The AFI has been created with the specic aim of attracting these parties to maximise the pro-independence representation at Holyrood.Mr Thompson plans to negotiate with them where their candidates should stand on the list system in order to boost the AFI’s chances of success.The organisation was formed in response to Holyrood’s electoral system, which was created to ensure parties that capture a high number of first-past-the-post constituency seats do not do so well when it comes to the top-up list seats, which are calculated by proportional representation.For example, at the last  Scottish election, the SNP did so well in the constituency vote – taking  out of  seats – that it won only four of the  top-up seats on the list system.Mr Thompson said the AFI would be contacting the Greens, Solidarity, the SSP and ISP shortly.“We will be inviting these four parties to come together with us and stand under the alliance banner. Our constitution is specically drawn up to allow for that. We have had discussions with the Electoral Commission over the principle of it. And we don’t anticipate any problem,” Mr Thompson said.“The only policy we will insist on is that they support independence and support the SNP Government in gaining independence. In all other matters, a small party can follow its own programme.”Our aim is to get anything from  to  of the regional list seats and, added to the SNP in terms of support for independence, that will give us a super-majority in parliament.”Dave Thompson of the Alliance for Independence The AFI will only field candidates for list seats and will encourage independence supporters to back the SNP in the constituencies.“We will be encouraging all Yes supporters to back the SNP, so they get the majority,not all, of the constituencies in Scotland next time. Our aim is to get anything from  to  of the regional list seats and, added to the SNP in terms of support for independence, that will give us a super-majority in parliament,” Mr Thompson said.But Mr Thompson’s overtures were roundly rejected by Mr Harvie, who added his voice to those who have accused the AFI of exploiting the rules to skew the parliament so it fails to represent the Scottish population as a whole.There is a huge dference between trying to put forward a distinct political proposition and trying to game the system and I think people will see through that as a transparently cynical move. I think it is more likely to leave people pretty disillusioned with that kind of game playing.”Patrick Harvie, Green co-convenerWhen askedhe would accept Mr Thompson’s invitation, Mr Harvie replied: “The simple answer to the simple question is no.”He added: “We have already selected our candidates for the election. But eventhat weren’t the case, Greens stand on a clear, well defined political .We have had Green MSPs elected in every single session of the Scottish Parliament and there is a huge dference between trying to put forward a distinct political proposition and trying to game the system and I think people will see through that as a transparently cynical move. I think it is more likely to leave people pretty disillusioned with that kind of game playing.”Mr Harvie, a well-known equality campaigner, also said he would not be willing to work with Mr Thompson because he had voted against same-sex marriage when he was an SNP MSP.“He’s part of the wing of the SNP that would have been opposed to equal marriage,” Mr Harvie said. “There is a real fundamental problem with asking people to join a political project with folk who don’t support their human rights.”The AFI has submitted its constitution to the Electoral Commission for approval and will hold an autumn conference at which potential Plan Bs to Nicola Sturgeon’s approach to independence are debated.Independence supporters have expressed frustration at the UK Government’s steadfast refusal to ignore Ms Sturgeon’s demands for a second independence referendum. Boris Johnson has ruled out granting the Section  Order required to pass the powers to hold a vote from Westminster to Holyrood.That sense of frustration has led to hardline independence supporters to call on the Scottish Government to explore a dferent route to splitting up the UK that would avoid a referendum that had been legally approved at Westminster.Plan B supporters have suggested an independence-supporting majority at next year’s Scottish elections should trigger the start of independence negotiations. Other suggestions have included a so-called “wild cat” unauthorised independence vote.Mr Thompson said these options would be debated at conference. But the alliance would not take a policy position on some of the most dficult and detailed issues surrounding independence, such as the currency, EU membership and the deficit.“One of the main aims is to get a second indyref and support the Scottish Government to get that. But we know that our members will wish to debate what happensthere is a continued refusal to grant a Section ,” Mr Thompson said.“So our membership will actually debate that at the end of September and we will come to a decision about what our position will be on it.”Responding to Mr Harvie’s remarks, Mr Thompson said the AFI would still be issuing formal invitations to the small parties and he hoped to discuss the situation with them, including the Greens.“We will wait until then to see what response we get,” he added.On Mr Harvie’s objection to the way he voted in the same-sex marriage debate of , Mr Thompson said he had since changed his views and would vote dferently now.As a Christian, Mr Thompson said he had followed the Church of Scotland’s discussions on the subject and had “thought and prayed a lot” about the issue.“I have no hesitation in saying that, as far as I’m concerned, I don’t believe homosexuality is a sin andI was in parliament voting on same-sex marriage again, I would actually support it,” Mr Thompson said.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t t t tDuration: n t t t t Month n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: dundee fc james mcpake kane hemmings
story: Dundee manager James McPake says he was surprised at Kane Hemmings’ U-turn on his Dark Blues future just days after agreeing a wage cut.The striker’s departure from Dens Park was announced today and immediately followed by the signing of a replacement striker Alex Jakubiak.Hemmings, , was the last of the first-team playing squad to accept reduced terms to help the club through the dficult financial period brought on by the coronavirus shutdown.However, McPake has revealed that agreement only lasted a couple of days before his former Dee team-mate asked to leave.McPake said: “It was a surprise when Kane phoned saying he wanted to leave because he’d agreed and signed his new contract.“But a couple of days later he said he#d changed his mind.“It’s disappointing but when a player doesn’t want to be at the club then it’s best they move on –particularly with what everyone  is doing.“You see the fans rallying round and everyone who entered the process, we’ve seen what they did.“It’s dficult and I know that, but the club is very together, there is a real feeling of everyone being in it together.“So it was disappointing to hear he didn’t want to stay.“I wish Kane all the best, but it’s time to focus on what we have here now.”On his new man Jakubiak, a former Scotland U  international who came through the Watford youth system, McPake says fans should expect a “more dynamic” striker when the season kicks off in October.“We are delighted to bring Alex in, he will bring real power and strength to the team,” he added.“He is a player we wanted to bring in anyway, title: dundee fc kane hemmings george cran
story: It’s been an unwanted saga at Dens Park this summer but, for the second time, striker Kane Hemmings has left Dundee.His first departure, for a reported fee of only £,, was a punch to the gut for fans of the Dark Blues as he headed south for Oxford United in  after scoring  goals the previous season.This one, however, has made contact a lot lower in what has been a testing summer for all who follow the Dens Parkers.Just as it felt like the tide was turning from negative headlines of financial losses, wage cuts and redundancies to more positive ones about players signing and fans rallying to raise money, Dundee were struck by a body blow from one of their main men.In June, Dark Blues managing director John Nelms spoke of “tough choices” to be made at the club following a loss of £, thanks to the early end to last season.The first cost-cutting move was to ask the first-team players to take a wage cut of % until October and then % until next May.A deadline was set for midnight on Friday, July , to respond with the threat of ‘Clause ’ – where clubs can suspend the contracts of playersmatches are suspended by the governing bodies # being invokedthey didn’t agree.The following day it emerged two players hadn’t met that deadline, one then swtly agreed but one remained outstanding.On the Sunday morning, Hemmings’ name was leaked as the one who hadn’t agreed to the cut, prompting huge speculation over where he would appear again in a Dundee shirt.Being one of the highest earners at the club, that % would be a bigger drop for him than almost every other squad member.However,  days after the deadline, Dundee announced all players had accepted the wage cut and it seemed their main striker would be sticking around for the   season.However, fast forward into August and Hemmings has indicated his desire to leave, putting a sizeable dent in manager James McPake’s plans for the new campaign.A day earlier, former St Mirren man Danny Mullen arrived, with supporters expecting him to complement the -year-old up top with his work-rate and energy.That won’t happen now but Mullen will team up with a team-mate of his from last term in Paisley, Alex Jakubiak.Meanwhile, it’s thought Hemmings has several clubs south of the border keen on his signature.Last season, the former Rangers and Cowdenbeath man took his time to get among the goals in his second spell at the club but, by the time of the shutdown, he had moved into double figures, showing the kind of goal-scoring form his manager brought him back for.Dundee fans only saw a fraction of what they knew he was capable of in the Championship – and that’s where the biggest frustration lies.Dundee boss James McPake reveals Jack Ross advice convinced him on Danny Mullen signing" title"#Dundee boss James McPake reveals Jack Ross advice convinced him on Danny Mullen signing# # title: dundee fc kane hemmings statement transfer news
story: Kane Hemmings has quit Dundee by mutual consent after making a dramatic U-turn on his future.The -year-old was initially the only member of the Dee squad who failed to agree a wage cut last month amid the financial pressures of the Covid- crisis.However, Hemmings, whose contract ran until , later indicated that he would be willing take a temporary salary reduction, sparking hopes that he could still have a part to play in Dundee#s promotion push next season.But Dee chiefs were left stunned when Hemmings # currently on holiday in Ibiza # informed them that he had changed his mind and requested his release for personal reasons.The Dark Blues said: #Dundee Football Club can confirm that Kane Hemmings has today left the club by mutual consent.#Kane re-joined the club in the summer of  and scored  goals throughout the   season.#We would like to thank Kane for his efforts while at Dens and wish him all the best for the future.#Dens Park boss James McPake is already eyeing potential replacements for the ex-Rangers and Cowdenbeath star.He is likely toto English football where he has previously turned out for Oxford United, Notts County, Barnsley and Mansfield.Burton Albion, who have already raided the SPFL to sign Steven Lawless from Livingston, are known to be interested in Hemmings and recently had a loan bid for the hitman kicked out by Dundee.Hemmings only ed to Tayside last summer and scored  goals in  outings during his second spell with the Dee, having previously found the net  times for the club in the   campaign.James McPake reveals Jack Ross advice convinced him on Danny Mullen signing" title"#James McPake reveals Jack Ross advice convinced him on Danny Mullen signing# # title: dundee united micky mellon transfer news
story: There have been a smattering rather than a procession of new arrivals at Dundee United but boss Micky Mellon insists they are ‘on the front foot’ with their recruitment drive.Mellon has raided the English market since taking over the reins at Tannadice, bringing in Manchester City youngster Luke Bolton on loan and snapping up defender Ryan Edwards from Blackpool.The former Tranmere boss is reportedly chasing Ipswich stars James Norwood and Toto Nsiala and, although he is keeping his cards close to his chest, says United have a few irons in the fire.“We are in the market,possible, to make Dundee United’s squad stronger,” he said.“I am careful to say squad because we have good players here but we are in the market all the time to try and make that better.“It is a continual on-going job because that is my job.“We will get linked to all sorts of players because we speak to agents but we have to be respectful to other clubs and players.“The clubs would be the first place we would go towe were to try and pursue something.”He continued: “The recruitment market can change on the toss of a coin.“It can be one that happens right away or it could be a slow burner where you are continually prodding at it.“There are a few we are prodding at the moment and trying to shake and things can change very quickly.“We are on the front foot and trying to improve the squad with some strong characters as quickly as we can.”Dundee United new boy Ryan Edwards has already shown he can win the toughest of all battles" title"#Dundee United new boy Ryan Edwards has already shown he can win the toughest of all battles# # However, Mellon is just delighted to have signed up a man he feels will be a key part of what he’s building.He added: “I am delighted to get him in.“I came into the group and got underneath it before I made any decisions on what type of players I needed to bring in.“It became very clear to me that we needed that type of central defender to compliment what we have already got.“Ryan is a leader, fantastic competitor and a good all-round guy.“He has come up here with bags of ambition and is looking to do really, really well.“He has an ambition to make a real impact.“He’ll be a good addition to the squad along with Luke Bolton and we are pleased that we have strengthened the group.”Mellon thinks his latest recruit has everything it takes to be a success in Scotland after spells with the likes of Blackburn Rovers, Morecambe and Plymouth Argyle.“I saw him right back in his Blackburn days,” he continued.“He is a centre back I have known for a long time.“He is a good size, a good athlete title: wild campers pollute dundee water supply
story: Wild campers are polluting land beside a reservoir which provides tap water for , people in Dundee and across Tayside.Scottish Water stressed the water is safe to drink but will be taking action after human excrement, rubbish and camping equipment were left on the shores of Lintrathen Loch outside Kirriemuir.Residents and community leaders are also up in arms, with one resident described the mess left behind as “foul and disgusting”.He said: “They have been coming here in their dozens camping at the shores of the loch then driving off and leaving all their rubbish behind them.”Gareth and Claire Finn, who run the Lodge of the Loch and the Wee Bear Cafe, said they counted  tents last weekend but reckoned more were hidden in the wooded area.Gareth said: “This is a new thing up here. We never normally get this number of people camping here.“I have no objection to people camping but surely there is no need to leave this amount of litter. There are no real facilities for litter, but people could be taking it home with them.”Scottish Water, which runs the loch and nearby Backwater Reservoir, said it had become increasingly frustrated at the “irresponsible behaviour of some visitors to the area, including so-called wild campers.”The utility company said fires were left on a beach, litter and rubbish was discarded at ious locations, pop-up tents and gazebos abandoned, and human excrement left behind.Brian McCarthy, Scottish Water’s reservoir manager, said: “All drinking water is monitored against stringent regulatory requirements and our treatment processes are designed to achieve these standards, but we would obviously urge people not to leave human waste near raw water reservoirs like Lintrathen in the first place.#We want everyone in the area to be able to enjoy the amenities around the reservoirs, as we do at reservoirs throughout Scotland, and to do so in a responsible way.”Councillor Julie Bell said she completely understood why people would want to enjoy the fresh air and go camping or for a day out at the beauty spot.“However, with the rights of access come the responsibilities enshrined in the Scottish Outdoor Access Code,” she said.“The culprits are not true ‘wild campers’ but are leaving a trail of destruction and mess. If they learn to respect the interests of other people,they truly care for the environment, andthey take responsibility for their own actions then they will become wild campers.”She said many local businesses were suffering from the impact of “thoughtless, destructive actions” while working so hard to rebuild, post-lockdown.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t t t tDuration: n t t t t Month n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: north east now online hub strives to connect locals with aberdeens lifestyle businesses
story: An online hub aiming to connect locals with the Granite City#s array of lestyle businesses has grown considerably since its inception.Launched in May, abz.le was established to help and encourage iniduals in the local area to support the fantastic businesses based on their doorsteps.It has since seen a surge of regional firms # from hairdressers, jewellers, photographers and boutiques, to bars, cafes and restaurants # keen to get involved in the hub, in order to promote and spread awareness of their services as much as possible.The listed directory is currently organised into a number of categories including: food and drink hair and beauty sports and fitness arts and crafts home and garden fashion and lestyle health and wellbeing and occasions and gts.With more than  Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire businesses listed, the number continues to grow by the day.On starting abz.le, co-founder Steph Eady said: #We actually had the idea to start abz.le last year.#But when lockdown began, we felt it was such an important time for us to develop and launch the hub as quickly as possible # as local companies required more support than ever before.#Even though there are so many people who want to support local, we felt there wasn’t an easy place to find these companies # especially those who only use Instagram or don’t have a website. So that’s why we wanted to create a hub where people can discover the huge number of amazing local businesses our city has.# vw, px"  Abz.le provides an easy way to discover, browse and connect with local lestyle businesses across the city and shire. Website visitors can utilise their categories and tags # to filter by # as well as an amazing search .#For local businesses, they can sign up for a free listing on our website # and provide us with links to their website and social media, customer testimonials, photos and more,# Steph, , added.#This then generates a beautul page that people can browse and contact them through. We direct traffic to their own channels, and we have also had loads of enquiries from users through our website, that get sent directly to these businesses.#We also feature the passionate people behind these businesses on our blog, so everyone can learn about them, be inspired by them, and support them.#I’m definitely proud of abz.le. This was a passion project for our team, and the support we’ve received has been incredible.#We get regular messages saying what a good idea this is, and we’ve also received many messages from our listed businesses saying they’ve had orders directly off the back of their listing or our social media posts # that makes it all worthwhile.#It’s a project that will always remind us of lockdown and the challenging times we all faced, but this is a very positive thing to come out of that. And we get such a buzz from meeting new business owners, learning about why they started and what they’re passionate about, and sharing their stories.#Similarly to the abz.le initiative, North-East Now was also launched in order to promote local businesses battling through the Covid- pandemic.The initiative – which is driven by Aberdeen  Grampian Chamber of Commerce and supported by creative agency Hampton, Aberdeen Journals, Original  and VisitAberdeenshire – will share inspirational and positive stories, encouraging people to do what they can to support the local economies in Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire.Steph said: #We spoke with the North-East Now team before they launched their campaign, as we have similar goals in terms of helping people support local wherever possible.#So it was fantastic to hear about their plans, and have abz.le included on their website. It’s a great feeling to be part of a big buy local movement, all supporting one another to get the best results for our city.#Abz.le is still very new, so we want to raise awareness of our  so we can help as many people as possible. The iety of companies listed on our website is absolutely incredible # and we want them all to be discovered and supported.#To find out more about North-East Now, visit northeastnow.scotTo share your positive business story, please email stories@northeastnow.scotFor as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Evening Express website including all Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening Express n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb and ePaper n t t t n t t t n t t t tDuration: n t t t tMonthly n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayUnlimited access to all articles on the Evening Express website. title: dave cormack very grateful aberdeens game with st johnstone not forfeited after positive covid 19 tests11
story: Aberdeen#s game with St Johnstone at McDiarmid Park has been moved to August .Chairman Dave Cormack earlier admitted he was grateful the game, initially scheduled for tomorrow lunchtime, had been postponed # rather than the Dons forfeiting it following a coronavirus outbreak at the club.The new Thursday evening slot will see the game broadcast on Sky Sports as was initially planned. As a result of the change, the Dons# home game with Livingston on Saturday, August  has been moved  hours to Sunday, August .Meanwhile, it is understood the SPFL are hopeful the Aberdeen v Hamilton this Wednesday and the Reds# trip to Celtic next weekend will go ahead as planned.A decision taken on Friday morning after a meeting between the Scottish Government, Scottish FA and SPFL resulted in the St Johnstone game being called off, despite early indications it was clear to go ahead.Cormack posted a video message on Friday morning asking for patience from supporters while the club ascertained the facts behind two players testing positive for Covid- and a further six requiring self-isolation. An internal investigation is already under way.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon condemned the actions of the players in her Friday lunchtime briefing, adding that she was #pretty furious# at the #completely unacceptable# situation.The city is already under additional lockdown measures after a Covid- spike, which has seen  new cases reported.Cormack, while saying the incident had undermined the work the club had done to resume football safely, admitted his gratitude at the club not being punished further.He said: “Given the signicant Covid- outbreak in Aberdeen, we fully understand why the Scottish Government has made this decision in the interests of public health.“With the pressure over this season’s fixtures, and the fact that we caused this problem, we were fully prepared to play the game tomorrow. We are very grateful that the decision has been to postpone, rather than forfeit the game.“I took the opportunity yesterday to apologise to both football and health authorities, and with our fellow premiership clubs today.“The clinical decision last night from the JRG that it was safe to play underlines the confidence the football authorities have in the robustness of our procedures and protocols. Regrettably, what has happened in the last few days has undermined all the hard work that has gone into keeping our players and staff safe. We are now dealing with this internally with the seriousness it deserves.“In the meantime, I’d like to reassure the relevant bodies, our fans and everyone associated with the club that our already rigorous measures are being forensically scrutinised and that no stone will be left unturned in ensuring that no-one is under any doubt about what must be adhered to.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Evening Express website including all Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening Express n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb and ePaper n t t t n t t t n t t t tDuration: n t t t tMonthly n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayUnlimited access to all articles on the Evening Express website. title: first minister nicola sturgeon says aberdeen players blatantly broke covid rules and confirms st johnstone premiership clash is off
story: First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has confirmed St Johnstone v Aberdeen is now off due to the Covid- outbreak at the Dons.It was confirmed last night two Aberdeen players # who are asymptomatic # had tested positive for the virus, while another six who had come into contact with the positive iniduals would have to join them in self isolating. The first positive inidual must isolate for  days as of Wednesday, while the other seven face  days of isolation.The decision meant eight Dons first-team stars would miss the Premiership game at St Johnstone tomorrow, as well as Hamilton#s Pittodrie visit on Wednesday and the trip to play Celtic at Parkhead next Saturday.An SFA SPFL Joint Response Group statement released last night said the televised game against Saints would go ahead, however, the Scottish Government has decided the game cannot take place at this time and must be postponed.Aberdeen city is currently in a local lockdown due to a spike in cases linked to a cluster of nightspots. All of the affected players were in a bar in the city centre after the - loss to Rangers on Saturday.The First Minister said: #They blatantly broke the rules agreed by the SFA, SPFL and Scottish Government. It is completely unacceptable.#This morning, the Scottish Government convened a meeting with the SFA and SPFL, and # following those discussions # the football authorities have confirmed the game between St Johnstone and Aberdeen in Perth will not go ahead.#It#s the right decision, we are expecting members of the public to behave in a highly precautionary manner right now and when a football club ends up with players infected with Covid, not through bad luck but through breaches of the rules, we cannot take even a small risk of them spreading it to other parts of the country.#Players are supposed to be in a #bubble# between their homes and the bio-secure Cormack Park training ground.The #furious# First Minister added: #Football has been given the go-ahead on the strict condition they abide by the strict conditions agreed. If they don#t do that, they put at risk theof the professional game.#I welcome Aberdeen#s statement they have reminded players of their obligations.#That#s important, footballers as we all know are role models and should behave accordingly.#It#s also important to remind the clubs to make sure their players are acting responsibly and in line with the guidance.#During the First Minister#s daily briefing, the SFA SPFL Joint Response Group released their own statement confirming the game was off, and it is as-yet-unclear whether the Dons# matches against Hamilton and Celtic will be affected.It said: #Following a meeting this morning between the Minister for Public Health, Sport and Wellbeing, Joe FitzPatrick, the Scottish FA Chief Executive, Ian Maxwell, and the Chief Executive of the SPFL, Neil Doncaster, to further examine the circumstances around the self-isolation of eight Aberdeen FC players, a request was received from Scottish Government # and agreement reached # to postpone Saturday’s Scottish Premiership match against St Johnstone.#There is an evolving public health outbreak in Aberdeen and the minister conveyed the need for additional work to provide further assurance around Aberdeen FC’s adherence to the agreed protocols.#Given the overriding responsibility to public health, the subsequent advice and discussion with the minister this morning means that the Joint Response Group must adhere to the request to postpone the match.#For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - title: letters to the editor june 26 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,In publishing the opinion piece #All lives matter# from your contributor on page  of the June  edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser, you have demonstrated a profound lack of understanding of the current Black Lives Matter protests.The tone-deaf piece is an attempt by your contributor to shut down engagement and perpetuate ignorance.How anybody can make the claim that all lives matter after witnessing such horric police brutality is beyond belief.All lives cannot matter until Black Lives Matter.Instead of deflecting and diluting the conversation, surely it is time to educate ourselves about what is happening, and to fight systemic injustice Madeleine Conn, ArdrishaigSir,The SNP continues to demonstrate its economic incompetence.New figures show the SNP government underspent its budget by a quarter of a billion pounds in -, and failed to use £ million of borrowing capacity. ​Instead of demanding further borrowing powers and more funding from the UK Government, the separatists should learn to use the resources they already have.With such colossal mismanagement, it#s no surprise that even senior SNP advisor Andrew Wilson has stated that Scotland is set to be the worst performing economy in the developed world. Once again, the separatists# numbers simply don#t add up.Councillor Alastair Redman # Kintyre and Islands wardSir,Exactly two years ago I was diagnosed with stage three, oestrogen positive breast cancer.I’d just come back from a week#s holiday in Spain with Isabel and Margaret. Days before I went on holiday I’d had a biopsy following referral from my GP. Although there wasn’t a cloud in the sky, my holiday was definitely clouded by impending results#I had chosen to wait until after my holiday to get them.The journey that Monday to go to Gartnavel is one I’ll never forget. My partner Frank didn’t shut up the whole way there, obviously he was nervous. I couldn’t be bothered with the small talk and just wanted him to shut up. Obviously I was nervous and he was just trying to keep my mind off it, but I was too busy silently praying. The number  is something I see all the time so I spent the whole journey looking for the number on someone’s licence plate #I saw it everything would be ok. I didn#t see it. That might sound a bit daft, but fear does crazy things to you.Walking into the consultant#s room and finding a nurse waiting there confirmed my worst fears. #It’s a wee cancer,# said Mr Wilson. The words echoing in my head, I couldn’t hear anything after that. I remember taking a deep breath and looking at Frank. I will never, ever forget the look on his face.My only question that day was #am I going to lose my breasts # The answer was no, and thankfully Frank was there to take in what was being said my head was spinning. The question I really wanted to ask was #am I going to die # I was too scared to ask that question.I didn’t cry until I walked out the hospital, then I bawled. Frank was amazing, and he didn’t talk like a budgie on the way home.The journey home was horrendous. I was terried about telling my mum. How do you tell your mum that her only child has cancer  I hadn’t told her anything about finding a lump. I couldn’t cope with worrying about her worrying about me # butit happens again I#d do it dferently and she’ll be the first to know. By the time I got home I had no more tears left.The relief telling mum was a huge weight off my shoulders. What ensued after my initial diagnosis was two weeks of crying every day. Telling the girls at work was so emotional, and in fact I was exhausted with it all.Once surgery and treatment plans were in place I was in a better place. Time to get the head down and get on with it, and that#s what I did. I was full of positivity and determination, and I think my sense of humour helped enormously.The treatment was bad, but it was necessary. The ongoing treatment is bad but it#s necessary. I’m alive and that’s what matters. My le has changed forever, nothing will be the same. My le has been ided into Before Cancer and After Cancer  I now have a new #normal#.I don’t know what the future holds, who does, but I intend to live my le happily, positively and most definitely to the fullest!I will never forget the support, both physically and emotionally that I received from my nearest and dearest, and of course from the whole community. The strength you have given me continues, and for that I am truly grateful.Please, pleaseyou find an abnormality or you just feel something isn’t quite right, act upon it and seek attention.I know it’s a dficult time with this horrid virus but it’s important to remember that early detection saves lives.Stay safe and take care.Yvie Young, Lochgilphead
