title: borders-cyclists-raise-5-000-katie-mckerracher-trust
story: THE magnicent edice of Bamburgh Castle provided a fitting backdrop to the completion of a -mile charity cycle undertaken at the weekend by two Borders couples.Selkirkrsquos Kenny and Shirley Houston, along with friends Andrew and Ann McKerracher of Ettrickbridge, had originally planned to take part in Aprilrsquos Etape Loch Ness cycling event, but its cancellation meant a complete rethink.Having already raised over pound, in sponsorship for the cancelled cycle, on Saturday the friends completed a similarly distanced route from the McKerrachersrsquo home in Ettrickbridge to the Northumberland village of Bamburgh .As well as finishing the -mile route in record time , what made the cyclistsrsquo achievement even more remarkable was the fact their sponsorship total has now rocketed to pound,.The money will go to the Katie McKerracher Trust, a charity established in  in memory of the McKerrachersrsquo -year-old daughter Katie, who died on January  that year from Dfuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma , a brain tumour on her brain stem.Since its formation in , the trust has assisted DIPG patients and their families in numerous ways ndash sending out copies of the trustrsquos DIPG information booklet, assisting with practical day-to-day issues, and working with health professionals to seek to improve the treatment of DIPG patients.Kenny, a retired police officer, chose the Bamburgh route as his mother Rhona hailed from the nearby village of Belford.At the end of the ride he said he had been ldquoabsolutely humbled by the number of people who had taken the time to support and sponsor the quartetrsquos efforts.ldquoThe sponsorship total has now increased to pound,, while the original aim had been to raise less than half of that.ldquoItrsquos a brilliant total to go to the Katie McKerracher Trust, which is a cause very dear to our hearts.Kennyrsquos we Shirley, a support officer at Hawick Police Station, said the cycle ride had been hard work but great fun.ldquoThe last eight miles was very hilly, but up until that point I couldnrsquot believe how quickly wersquod been going.ldquoThe favourable weather conditions helped, so all-in-all things couldnrsquot have gone any better.Friends, family and well-wishers gathered at Bamburgh to cheer the four cyclists across the finishing line, and the champagne flowed as everyone toasted the ridersrsquo superb efforts.ldquoEverything went pretty much according to plan, said Andrew McKerracher, whose parents Donald and Moira travelled down from their home in Perth to set up feed stations for the cyclists at Kelso and Ford.ldquoThere was plenty of good banter among the four of us ndash especially during the hilly climbs, added Andrew, who is vice-president procurement  supply chain with Galashiels-based pharmaceutical firm Kyowa Kirin International plc.,params: .pushldquoWe are very grateful to everyone who supported us on the day, and also to the many kind iniduals whorsquove made such generous donations.ldquoThe money raised will be invaluable in helping to further the trustrsquos work.To date, cycling events have played a major role in the Katie McKerracher Trustrsquos fundraising efforts.Ann McKerracher said the first major task was the Hebridean Cycle Challenge in .But reflecting on the most recent ride, Mrs McKerracher hailed an ldquoenjoyable cycle.The foster parent and Borders College achievement coach added: ldquoThe cycle to Bamburgh was a great experience, made all the more enjoyable by the support of family and friends along the way.ldquoThe most satisfying thing, however, is the fact so much money has been raised for the trust thanks to the generosity and kindness of supporters.Kenny Houstonrsquos fundraising exploits are well-known throughout the Borders and beyond. Diagnosed with bowel cancer in , and having undergone five major surgeries over the past five years, in  he organised a dinner and auction in support of the BGHrsquos Borders Cancer Centre and the Katie McKerracher Trust, with each organisation receiving a sum in excess of pound,.Last April he staged a dinner-dance and auction in Selkirkrsquos Haining House, raising a further pound, for the Borders Cancer Centre.He said: ldquoIrsquom delighted the four of us are raising funds for the Katie McKerracher Trust.ldquoShirley and I were extremely fond of Katie, and the trust has done an amazing job of supporting DIPG patients and their families over the past  years.Anyone still wishing to make a donation can do so through this website.

title: borders-workers-face-redundancy-johnstons-elgin
story: JOBS are at risk at Johnstons of Elgin in the Borders.The cashmere specialist has warned that  staff roles are under threat at its Hawick mill and Innerleithen premises.Further jobs are expected to go at the firms head office in Elgin, which also has a satellite site in Walkerburn.Simon Cotton, CEO of Johnstons of Elgin, said: ldquoWhile Johnstons of Elgin has strong long-term prospects, to meet the signicant short and medium-term impact of the COVID- pandemic we are restructuring the business."This reflects the new realities we are facing with stores in most of our markets around the world having been closed for several months and now faced with reducing high stock levels."Our community in Hawick is at the heart of our business as well as the incredible skills and capabilities of our team, therefore this is not a decision we have taken lightly, but out of necessity to protect the long-term health of the business."We will do everything within our power to mitigate the number of redundancies but we know that this will be an unsettling time for our workforce and our intention is to manage this process quickly and fairly."Our priority will be to maintain our exceptional skills and capabilities so that we can build on these in the future as the situation starts to improve again."

title: company-wants-hire-100-people-borders-town
story: AN ENERGY supplier says it will hire  people in the Borders in the coming months.Peoplersquos Energy is taking over the former OVO Energy offices in Selkirks Ettrick Riverside building at Dunsdale Road.Peoplersquos Energy co-founder David Pike says the Borders has a "lot of talented people trained in the [energy] sector".Local MP John Lamont hailed the news as ldquovery welcome, nodding to the number of workers who have lost their jobs during the coronavirus pandemic.Mr Pike, , said the new roles will include ndash but not be limited to ndash call centre positions.He said: "We will obviously help the local economy and well be able to continue the tradition of energy sector work."We have customers who vote on local representatives to sit on advisory boards ndash we want to include people in our management."Peoples Energy is a community initiative business, for the people, by the people."In May, OVO Energy revealed that nearly  jobs would be lost at its Selkirk site.In response to the Peoples Energy announcement, Mr Lamont, of the Conservatives, said: "This is very welcome news that comes amid a spate of job losses in the Borders."I am delighted that Peoplersquos Energy are able to tap into the energy expertise in Selkirk left behind from previous employers in the town.ldquoIt would be a shamethis industry knowledge had been lost."This is a vote of confidence in the area and I hope that Peoplersquos Energy will have many successful years here."Peoplersquos Energy hopes to use the next  months to establish itself and build its workforce, but the company is also hoping to eventually grow further.Mr Pike said: "I see no reason not to expand ndash weve got the space."Were growing rapidly. This last month weve grown by , customers ndash , overall."We also want to address fuel poverty."We want our prepaid tarf to be as close to our direct debit tarf as people with prepaid tarfs are potentially more likely to be in fuel poverty."South of Scotland Enterprise chairman Russel Griggs was present at Peoplersquos Energyrsquos launch at Ettrick Riverside.Professor Griggs said: ldquoPeoplersquos Energyrsquos expansion into Selkirk and the potential of new jobs is fantastic news for the community.ldquoThe Borders has a fantastic reputation for high quality customer service and expertise in the energy sector and I see this as a much-needed boost for Selkirk, and the wider south of Scotland economy.Christine Grahame MSP ndash who represents Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale ndash said she ldquoheartily welcomes the plans.She said: ldquoThe creation of  jobs would be good news at any time but even more so now during the pandemic and accompanying economic crisis.The company also plans to reward customers through its profit share scheme, which aims to give customers back  per cent of profits as a rebate ndash either a bill reduction or account credit.However, as a new company, Peoplersquos Energy requires stability before making good on this, according to Mr Pike.

title: results-day-borders-school-pupils-praised-hard-work
story: SCHOOL pupils have been praised by Scottish Borders Councilas they received their qualication results todayfollowing an unusual academic year.The coronavirus lockdown meant exams were cancelled, so grades were based on estimates made by teachers.SBC leader Shona Haslam hailed pupils for having ldquorisen to the challenge set by the lockdown.Mrs Haslam said: "This yearrsquos students have been faced with an unprecedented situation and they are to be commended for the remarkable flexibility and resilience that they have shown in the circumstances."Around , exams were sat in the Borders this academic year, with , at Higher,  at Advanced Higher and , at National .This year, S students sitting exams at National  SCQF Level , with grades ranging from A to C, achieved a pass rate of . per cent. And overall, attainment at SCQF Levels - increased.Borders schools also remain in the top quartile nationally for positive destinations, with . per cent of students achieving a "positive and sustained destination".Mrs Haslam extended her praise and thanks to members of Borders teaching staff.She said: "Teaching staff have worked extremely hard together with the SQA to make sure that the assessment process has been as fair and transparent as possible and there has been minimal impact on our young people and what they have been able to achieve."As a result of that determination, it is encouraging to see that Scottish Borders has attained a set of results which demonstrate a picture of consistent achievement."In S exams sat in May this year in core subjects such as Literacy and Numeracy,  per cent of students achieved a literacy award, with  per cent achieving a National  English award.In numeracy,  per cent of S students received a numeracy award, with . per cent awarded a National  in maths.Mrs Haslam added: "Exam results day is one of the most momentous events in a young personrsquos le at the best of times.ldquoThis yearrsquos students have been faced with an unprecedented situation and they are to be commended for the remarkable flexibility and resilience that they have shown in the circumstances.ldquoIt is encouraging to see that our commitment to preparing our young people for their next steps in le continues to pay idends, with an increasing number of them being able to leave education with higher levels of qualications and attainment and move on to positive and title: author-sebastian-barry-says-borders-magical-allure
story: Sebastian Barry, the current Laureate for Irish Fiction, is sad to miss Melrose and the ldquomagical allure of the Borders this year.The Costa-winning author of Days Without Endand A Long, Long Way, booked to appear at this yearrsquos Borders Book Festival, has visited Melrose three times, and the area clearly made an indelible mark on him.He said: ldquoIf yoursquore going to be spoiled in this lehellip twice I went [to Melrose] and for mysterious reasons they gave me the Walter Scott Prize [for Historical Fiction] each time."And then another time I was thrilled to go to give the prize to Benjamin Myers.ldquoAll three times not only did I slowly gather a friendship with [festival director] Alistair [Moffat], who was really a great guy, but we were so spoiled, I donrsquot knowwe were fit for human le after that."We had to come back to normal places after that.He continued: ldquoThe Borders held a magical allure for me. You donrsquot just want to go there ndash you need to get back to it.ldquoWhen Irsquom  and trying to think of the signal things that have happened to me as an old critter writer going around, thatrsquoll be high up on the list. Just the welcome of it.Though Barry wonrsquot be able to meet his readers in person this year, he will be talking to an online audience on August  about his latest book, A Thousand Moons.Sequel to rsquos Days Without End, A Thousand Moonsis set in  Tennessee and narrated by native American Winona, who tells of her unorthodox upbringing by two men and her quest for revenge after she endures a brutal attack.Barry spoke to the Border from his home in County Wicklow, on a beautul morning that he predicted with nonchalance would not last.ldquoJust for two hours itrsquos summer ndash itrsquos really beautul, about  degrees, wersquove just had coffee outside, just to feel it.ldquoAnd then it will give way to rain for the rest of eternity, sohellip But in this moment, itrsquos good.Unable to travel to promote A Thousand Moonsor visit the ious book festivals that would normally be on his itinerary, Barry has spent much time in the mountains that look down on his home.He has also been reading books such as Meditationsby Marcus Aurelius ndash works that are ldquostrong winds to stir away the fog of the pandemic.He is sanguine about the impact of lockdown on his book festival plans.ldquoIrsquom a slightly introverted person so doing the festivals does require an effort of mind for me, he said, ldquobut nevertheless now I donrsquot have them, I realise even more how unusual they are.ldquoEspecially for godless folk like myself, itrsquos a kind of reaffirmation of humankind, because you do your reading and yoursquore there talking to your fellow writers, especially at the Borders Book Festival because they have it arranged like that.,params: .pushldquoItrsquos very important for the participants to be among each other as well.He added: ldquoThe aftermath of it is that you have your signing queue. Andyoursquore very old like me ndashyoursquore  ndash you might have some people in the signing queue and thatrsquos a really lovely thing because each person comes up and says oftentimes quite private things to you.ldquoEveryone is on their best behaviour. Yoursquore on your best behaviour! And therersquos just a sort of clemency about it."Therersquos some very deep magic in it and I miss that.But Barry is positive about the book festivalrsquos online efforts to bring its ldquomagic to readers.ldquoDoing it online reaffirms the importance of people gathering to talk about books, to meet the people who make books, to meet the people who read books, he said.ldquoAt a certain level it doesnrsquot sound a lot but actually it turns out to be a huge thing that wersquore now going to have to miss, and itrsquos wonderful the effort thatrsquos being made to perpetuate it.ldquoThis is going to be our effort to sort of be there, like a sympathetic magic, like a group of admirable witches brewing up something that feels like the real thing.To see Sebastian Barry in conversation with Mairi Kidd, Creative Scotlandrsquos Head of Literature, Languages and Publishing, you can click this link.The festival is sponsored by investment management company Baillie Gford.

title: schools-reopening-20-public-buses-taken-pupils
story: PAYING passengers will be banned from  bus services in the Borders as schools .Scottish Borders Councilhas announced that  routes are being deregistered from public use from August , so more room will be available for pupils.SBC chief executive Tracey Logan said: ldquoIt is important to emphasise that while many of the services being closed off to the public may have theoretically been open for public use, the uptake has historically been extremely low, and in some cases unused entirely.To see the full list of routes being taken over for school children only, readers can visit the councilrsquos website.When pupilsto classrooms on Tuesday, five months after the coronavirus pandemic prompted the closure of schools, they will not have to obey social-distancing or wear face coverings. The same will apply to students using school transport.However, pupils will have to use hand sanitiser when they board buses, and the vehicles will be cleaned thoroughly.While unveiling these measures, the council also announced that  public bus services will be taken over for school-use only. The council says the move is designed to ldquomaximise capacity for pupils.Affected routes include the Borders Buses service P from Borders Busesand the Telfords service S .Ms Logan said: "In all instances,any member of the public who would normally use the services still needs to travel and there is no alternative public transport, the council will provide assistance."Anyone in this situation should contact our Passenger Transport team on PLACEtransport@scotborders.gov.uk or call   ."Throughout the rest of this week we will be providing regular updates and information for parents, carers and pupils on all aspects of theto school, all of which can be accessed online at www.scotborders.gov.uk schoolreopening"On buses which will contain both pupils and paying customers, the pupils will be given a dedicated section of the bus. Everyone will have to obey social distancing and wear masks.Services which require pupils to follow government COVID- guidelines include Borders Buses XBorders Buses and Telfords H .

title: m-co-hawick-peebles-stores-saved-closure
story: RETAIL workers at MCo stores in the Borders will keep their jobs, the fashion giant says.MCo is closing  shops across the UK, meaning  people will be made redundant.But the Peebles and Hawick stores will remain open, according to a company spokesman.He said: ldquoIrsquom pleased to confirm that both the Peebles and Hawick stores will remain open following MCorsquos restructuring.MCo appointed an administrator in April after taking a financial hit from coronavirus.The administration process, led by Deloitte, will see the number of stores cut from  to , with around  redundancies from a total workforce of more than ,.MCorsquos chief executive Andy McGeoch said: ldquoIt quickly became clear that the best way to save most jobs and most stores was to enter administration, with a new company acquiring the assets of the old business, and this process has now been finalised.ldquoCOVID has been by far the biggest challenge our family business has faced in almost  years, and I am really pleased that we have been able to maintain a presence in over  communitiesldquoCOVID- means many people donrsquot feel comfortable travelling on public transport or visiting busy city centres and that can be good news for local high street stores like MCo.ldquoThatrsquos why we are looking at ways of working in partnership with other local retailers to highlight the tremendous range of shopping that can be found in communities like this all over the country.ldquoLocal economies rely to a huge degree on their town centres and we have seen too many high streets hollowed out by successive shop closures.ldquoMore and more people are beginning to realise that,they donrsquot support their town centres, everyonersquos quality of living really takes a hit, so we are proud to be playing a part in the drive to shop locally.

title: youtube-vlogger-ban-cars-melrose-high-street
story: A VISITOR to Melrose has claimed traffic is spoiling the town.YouTube user Edward Burns, , of Glasgow, recently visited Melrose during a walk to the statue of William Wallace at the Bemersyde estate.But during a break, Mr Burns told viewers that he was unable to film at the Market Cross because the sound of passing traffic was too loud."It was just the clamour," Mr Burns said. "Ive been [to Melrose] a few times before, but at the Mercat Cross there were so many cars going past."In his video, Mr Burns suggests that the High Street should be closed off to cars, with the exception of mobility vehicles and delivery vans.He told the Border : "Im not suggesting that the High Street should be completely closed."The number of cars affects the enjoyment you can have."Where the pavements are narrower, you feel you cant stop and look in shop windows - theres not enough space."The Border put this complaint to Melrose and District Community Council.The community councilrsquos chairman William Windram said: "Its not an issue weve had raised."People parking for longer than they should, yes ndash but no one has called for a ban."Parking is a problem."We have other parking but its not close to the High Street."I dont think a parking-free zone will work."A spokesperson from Scottish Borders Council added: "The council is not currently considering any changes of this kind to the road network in Melrose."When the council introduced the current one-way system and townscape improvements to Melrose town centre, a wide range of stakeholders were involved."These improvements aimed to strike a balance between creating a more pedestrian-friendly environment without impacting adversely on the needs of local businesses."Mr Burns says stress can be caused by being around cars.He said: "Lots of cars can create stress."A lot of cars and a lot of people, it can take away from the experience of being somewhere and taking in the things around you."What are your views on this topic Please let us know by sending an email to editorial@bordertelegraph or message our Facebook page at: www.facebook bordertelegraph

title: scotland-schools-reopening-survey-reveals-teachers-really-feel
story: A survey by Scotlandrsquos largest teaching union shows major safety concerns ahead of the reopening of schools next week.EIS conducted the survey, with interim results earlier this week showing less than one in five are confident that schools are currently safe.How many teachers completed the survey A total of , teachers completed the survey from its launch on Tuesday  August to the morning of Thursday  August.What do the teachers say While teachers want to see schools reopen, they remain unconvinced that sufficient measures have been put in place to ensure safety.The survey shows % of teachers support the decision to reopen schools.However only % express confidence that schools are currently safe ndash indicating that much more needs to be done to ensure safety.Just % of teachers are lsquovery confidentrsquo that there is sufficient evidence that COVID- is sufficiently under control to support a safeto school.And less than a quarter of teachers are lsquoconfident or very confidentrsquo that an established capacity to test, trace and isolate is in place to support a safe , with % expressing a lack of confidence.Interim Survey Results Highlight Teacher Concerns over Schools Reopening Next Week #EISNewshttps:t.co MKVWQAWeAmdash EISAugust , The survey also found that around % of teachers are confident that sufficient operational changes ndash such as effective social distancing and enhanced hygiene routines ndash will be in place to support a safeto school with % lacking confidence.And % of teachers feel either lsquosomewhat unsafersquo or lsquovery unsafersquo about ing to school next week.What does the teaching union say Commenting on the interim findings, EIS general secretary Larry Flanagan said:ldquoThe interim results of this survey highlight that Scotlandrsquos teachers continue to have serious questions over the re-opening of schools next week.ldquoThe fact that more than , teachers completed the survey in a little over a day illustrates the high degree of concern that remains over COVID- and schools.ldquoTeachers want to see schools reopening, so that they can get back to working with pupils in the classroom environment ndash but they are very clear that this has to be done safely.ldquoThe initial indications from this major survey confirm that teachers believe that much more still needs to be done to ensure their safety, and the safety of pupils and others within the school, can be properly protected as schools reopen."The EIS will be sharing both the initial and final results of this survey with the Scottish Government and local authorities, and will be seeking urgent discussions on the mitigations that teachers still want to see ndash such as sufficient social distancing, testing for asymptomatic staff, and the use of face coverings where required to ensure safety.,params: .pushScotlands schools will re-open full-time from  August, following scientic evidence and advice that it is safe to do so.Weve published guidance to support local authorities, teachers and parents to prepare for the new term.Read the guidance at https:t.co fcuOhEZjpic PKCJIZjmdash Scottish GovernmentAugust , When are schools back Scotlandrsquos schools are to reopen full time from August .What have the Scottish Government said A Scottish Government spokesman previously told the PA: "Ensuring the highest quality education for our young people, in a safe environment, is our absolute priority, and we also want to make sure teaching staff feel supported."Our guidance clearly sets out the approach that must be taken, including a number of specic risk-mitigation measures that will need to be introduced in all schools in order that they provide a safe environment for staff and pupils."Inidual schools will carry out risk assessments on their estate, as they will know how to apply the guidance in a way that works best to ensure the safety of their setting."An enhanced surveillance programme for schools will allow us to closely monitor the impact of the pandemic on school age children and young people and staff and to make adjustments to the arrangements as necessary."

title: borders-town-eager-go-green
story: SELKIRK environmentalists say locals have been "enthusiastic" about their new pop-up shop to help with recycling, home energy and environmentally friendly transport.Sustainable Selkirk, part of Selkirk Regeneration, opened on July  at  Tower Street, working alongside the Selkirk Parish Church Eco Group.Sustainable Selkirkrsquos project coordinator, Iain McLachlan, told the Border : "Our goal is to support people in Selkirk to reduce carbon emissions through local transport and at home."As well as offering support for clearing out recyclables, Sustainable Selkirk is offering advice and support for Souters wanting to make an environmental change in how they get around or what energy they use at home.And once lockdown restrictions are lted further, Mr McLachlan and his team hope to offer at-home visits to assess what people can do to be more energy efficient."Were taking names for our free home energy assessment," Mr McLachlan explained."Well go around with the homeowner and see what they can do to save money and help the environment. Well also offer personalised advice."Its really important to be energy efficient ndash for our health and for the environment."Whats good for a person is good for the planet."After marking their second week at  Tower Street, Mr McLachlan and home energy adviser Kasha Jarosz noted that there was "so much enthusiasm" from visitors to the shop who wanted a space for the climate conversation and to make changes."Having an energy-efficient home is good for our health, and so is having energy-efficient transport," said Mr McLachlan."Were aware of air pollution and how high levels of driving contribute to that."We want to help people to make changes, like walking or cycling more. We even have training on how to drive efficiently."Theres real enthusiasm for wanting to help take steps for health and the environment."When asked about his own reasons for joining Selkirk Regeneration, Mr McLachlan said: "It [environment] is something that mattered [to me] for years."The more aware I became, and as the science tells us to make changes, I realised how easy it was to make those changes."Personally its really important, and it benefits the community."The shop, which is set to move to  Tower Street once renovation work is completed, has necessary COVID- measures in place such as only two visitors at a time, screens and sanitisation stations.

title: face-masks-scotland-mandatory-wearing-expanded-new-laws-visors
story: THE First Minister has announced an expansion of the law around wearing face coverings in Scotland.Currently, people in Scotland must wear some form of mask or covering on both public transport and in shops.Speaking at her daily briefing in Edinburgh, Nicola Sturgeon said initial evidence suggests that compliance with those rules are very high.The wearing of face coverings in enclosed spacesis already in public guidance, but with Scotlands gradual move out of lockdown continuing, the First Minister announced further locations in which it would become mandatory.Where will I have to wear a mask Wearing a covering will now become mandatory in these situations:Places of worshipMuseumsLibrariesOther indoor spaces - details to come on Scottish Government website.Full details will be available on the Scottish Government website.When will the changes come into force The changes will take place from Friday, August .What was said about visors The First Minister saidthat evidence suggests the wearing of face visors on their own is not enough.From next Friday, a face visor must be accompanied with another form of face covering.How will it be enforced The First Minister did not go into detail regarding this, however it is likely it will be enforced in a similar way to those on public transport and in shops.She previously said it would be "not fair or reasonable" to expect shop workers to enforce the rules - and instead it would be down to the police to do so.Fixed penalty notices - which start at pound - could be handed out by the police, but she says they will do so only at a last resort.Ms Sturgeon added: "All of us can help by doing this voluntarily because it can make a dference".Who is exempt Children under five will be exempt from this rule, Ms Sturgeon confirmed, along with those with certain medical conditions.Based on the public transport rules, the following groups may also be exempt:Police officers first responders in an emergencyStaff separate by a physical barrier ndash including bus drivers behind a screenAnyone with ahealthcondition where a mask would cause dficulty, including asthmaYou need to take medicationTo speak with someone who lip readsWhen asked to remove it by a relevant authority, e.g. Police officer.But Ms Sturgeonsaid: ldquoFor everyone , face coverings will be mandatory."What  was announced The First Minister also announced that it will become mandatory by law for hospitality venues to take contact details for all customers.This is to help with the NHS Scotland Test and Protect schemeto stop the spread of the virus.

title: party-mansion-could-spread-coronavirus-borders
story: A BORDERS mansion has come under fire amid claims that large and rowdy groups have visited the property during the coronavirus pandemic.Residents of The Loan, West Linton, say the Greenloaning Mansion has hosted large groups of guests since lockdown rules changed to allow hospitality businesses to reopen.Neighbour John Thompson: "Everybodys at the end of their tether.The owner of the mansion, Edinburgh businessman Michael Cameron, has refuted the allegations through his lawyer.However, residents insist large, noisy gatherings have visited the mansion in recent weekends. Some residents fear COVID- could be spread through West Linton as a result.The Scottish Governments lockdown guidance states that indoor gatherings should be capped at eight people, from up to three households.Mr Thompson said: "Were [residents speaking up] representing the feelings of those living on the road."A couple are struggling with their mental health on this."Mr Thompson, who has children aged seven and nine, added that the activity at the mansion has affected his children too.He said: "We were meant to be in Spain in July, but we couldnt go, so I bought the kids a tent to put in the garden."But when we went to use it, the parties started."Mr Cameron did not wish to provide a statement when contacted by the Border , but he pointed to comments sent by his solicitor to the Edinburgh Evening News.That statement reads: ldquoThe complaints alleged are not accepted nor justied."Mr Cameron, in letting the property, has always and will continue to abide by the COVID- rules and principles for self-catering accommodation."Some self-catering accommodation was able to reopen on June , with more opening on July  and .Duncan McKenzie, another of Greenloanings neighbours, says he has contacted local MSP Christine Grahame about the weekend visitors.He said: "For the past four weekends there have been gatherings of up to  or ."I have spoken to Christine Grahame MSP and she assures me that the police can and should break up the gatherings, take names and addresses for track and trace,necessary, and fine peopleappropriate."She plans to take this up with senior officers."Ms Grahame, of the SNP, who represents Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale, said: "There have been long-standing complaints from residents about the activities at Greenloaning Mansion and the disturbance caused in particular by the regular hen and stag parties renting the facilities, complete with jacuzzi."This has been exacerbated since reopening in July as large groups have rented the premises with additional concerns about the risk of importing COVID- to the village."A recent group of men attending a stag do came from London and I understand the police, who have attended the premises on many occasions because the men were so drunk, could not safely disperse them.ldquoSo for the lawyer acting for Michael Cameron to claim that COVID- security measures were being observed beggars belief."The council and the police I know are working to resolve this ongoing problem which I hope is concluded soon and have promised to keep me informed."In response to claims that a multi-agency meeting between Scottish Borders Counciland Borders police will be held to discuss the issues raised by residents of The Loan, an SBC spokesperson said: "The council has been made aware of these concerns and is working with partners to seek to bring a resolution to the matter."The website for Greenloaning Mansion states: ldquoThis prestigious, award-winning mansion is set in over an acre of wooded garden in the delightful conservation village of West Linton.ldquoThis is the perfect setting for large parties of up to  guests to enjoy the extensive amenities the mansion has to offer.

title: heatwave-six-ways-cool-house---common-mistakes-avoid
story: It might be hotting up outdoors -butyoursquore stuck inside and struggling to keep cool, there are a iety of things todo to make your room cooler.Weve put together a handy heatwave guide to help.Close the curtains and windowsAlthough the first thing you might want to do on a warm and sunny day is to open the curtains and let some air in through the windows, this can sometimes make a room hotter.If the temperature is hotter outside than inside, then you could just be letting warm air in.However,you do open the windows, try to do so in a way which will encourage a through draft.Opening a lower window from the cooler side of your house and an upper window from the hotter side can help, making sure that all doors and windows are open from one end of the house to the other in order to let the air easily move through.During the night, the temperature tends to fall, soitrsquos possible, open your bedroom window a little to let a cooling breeze in as you sleep.Hanging a wet sheet in front of an open window can also help to bring the temperature in the room down.Turn the lights offLights can emit extra heat that can make your room warmer, soitrsquos not dark outside, turning them off can help to keep a room cooler.Turn electrical appliances offSimilarly to light bulbs, electrical appliances radiate heat which can make an already warm room even hotter.Unplug your phone, TV and other devices that may be radiating heat and donrsquot charge them overnightyoursquore trying to keep cool as you sleep.Use cotton or linen sheetsIf your bedroom is warm and yoursquore finding it too hot to sleep, using cotton or linen sheets can help.This is because they are breathable fabrics and better at keeping you cool than materials such as polyester.This also counts for clothes, so wearing a cotton or linen top and trouser will be cooler than heavier fabrics.If you have time when changing your sheets, you can put them in the freezer for around  minutes beforehand, so theyrsquoll feel cool when you get into bed.Make sure you place your sheets in a plastic bag before putting them in the freezer to make sure nothing spills on them and that they remain clean.FanA fan can be a good way of cooling a room down, and is a popular choice with many when the mercury rises.Placing a bowl of iced water in front of the fan can also be an extra step in keeping a room cool. This will make the air feel cool as the ice evaporates.Avoid things that can cause humidityA hot shower, the washing machine and the dishwasher all produce steam which can cause humidity and make a room feel even warmer.Use them as little as possible when a room is already too warm.

title: east-lothians-football-teams-back-september
story: The countyrsquos six senior football teams have been left on the sidelines since March, when the coronavirus pandemic brought the season to a premature close.Now, early discussions have identied a possible start for the new campaign.The Lowland East South West Pyramid group ndash representing teams from the Scottish Lowland Football League, the East of Scotland Football League, the South of Scotland Football League and the West of Scotland Football League ndash held its first Zoom call earlier this month.Clubs are hoping to restart training in the coming weeks, with a view to playing again at the end of September or beginning of October.Managers from East Lothianrsquos teams cautiously welcomed the announcement and hoped it was the start of light at the end of the tunnel.Geoff Jones, manager of Dunbar United, said: ldquoI think, to be honest, it is an enormous boost.ldquoNot just from a football perspective but just a mental health perspective as well ndash for a lot of people to get back to doing some level of group interaction.ldquoWe have pushed ndash as have a lot of clubs ndash inidual training programmes through virtual apps, like Strava, but some people are highly motivated and others find it dficult outwith a group environment.Meanwhile, Johnny Harvey was looking forward to starting his first full season in charge of Tranent Juniors, having been appointed in February.The Foresters Park side will be looking to build on a promising campaign, which saw them sitting fourth in the East of Scotland Football League Premier Division when the season was stopped.Harvey said: ldquoTo get some kind of normality back in everybodyrsquos lives would be a huge boost.ldquoSupporters, players, myself ndash everybody is exactly the same and is excited to get back on the field as soon as possible.Kevin McDonald, manager at Musselburgh Athletic, was frustrated to see football halted in the spring with his side on an impressive run of form, including securing a place in this seasonrsquos Scottish Cup after a - thumping of Mid Annandale in the South and East Shield.Now, he is hoping to see that continue when the upcoming campaign gets under way.He said: ldquoI have been pestering the secretary at Musselburgh to find outhe has any information.ldquoWe are all desperate to get back ndash myself and the players are the same.ldquoWe will be looking at a seven-month break by the time we restart games.ldquoThe sooner we are allowed to get back training and playing friendlies the better.ldquoI think we will need more friendlies with not playing for so long as well.Joe Hamill, player-manager at Haddington Athletic, said everyone at the club was keen to see the season get back under way.He stressed that training could look slightly dferent than it did previously, with stringent cleaning measures being put in place to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.He said: ldquoItrsquos a wee bit of light at the end of the tunnel for us. Irsquove been getting messages from the players asking lsquowhen are we starting back rsquoldquoIrsquom in the same boat and just want to get on with it.

title: pans-snake-slithers-across-road-new-home
story: The Pans Snake has stretched from the eastern edge of Prestonpans towards neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton since it was born at the beginning of April.However, with plans for a temporary cycle path to be created beside busy Edinburgh Road, the snake had to find a new home... on the other side of the road.Emma Orphant was among those spending  minutes on Sunday evening moving the snake from the north side of the road.She said: ldquoWe lost count of the number of stones at ,!ldquoWe moved them across the road because the council are putting in a temporary cycle path.ldquoOn Sunday, volunteers and children moved them across the road.ldquoIt has just been a nice thing for people when they are out for a walk to look for.ldquoIt is for the kids.Youngsters and adults started working on the Pans Snake at the beginning of April, with lockdown restrictions in effect.Similar schemes have taken place where across the country, including the Windygoul Worm in Tranent.The snake started at the bus stop beside the Greenhills at Prestonpans, with Emma, who is depute manager at Seahorse Nursery in Cockenzie, keen to see it stretch the near half-mile to the neighbouring village.Emma, who lives in Prestonpans, was pleased to say that the snake had been a success and admitted she had a few favourite stones.She picked out those from youngsters saying they were missing school or with messages including their name and teacherrsquos name from school as her favourites.Beyond the coronavirus, Emma ndash and a number of people on social media ndash was keen to see the snake find a permanent home, with the possibility of the stones being cemented into the wall beside the footpath.

title: beach-boardwalk-look-blooming-great-thanks-volunteers
story: The team has been working hard over the last fortnight to create plant beds along one side of the walkway as it carries out landscaping work on the site.The boardwalk was created two years ago across the road from the holiday village to provide easy access to the beach for wheelchair users and, thanks to grants from the Walk With Scott Foundation and Beach Wheelchairs charity, two beach wheelchairs are available to borrow from Seton Sands.Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom said that the boardwalk, which also has three picnic tables and seats, had become a popular place for locals and holidaymakers all year round and members were delighted to be able to start work on its surroundings.A spokesperson said: ldquoIt was always our intention to landscape the area around the boardwalk and we are delighted that this work has finally got under way.ldquoOver the last two weeks, members of Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom, assisted by several enthusiastic and hard-working volunteers, have transformed one side of the boardwalk.ldquoA long raised bed has been sited alongside the pavement.ldquoA rockery has been created at the beginning of the boardwalk.ldquoSoil was provided by East Lothian Council and the areas planted up with plants suitable for the exposed situation near the sea, which will, in time, provide colour and interest for most of the summer.ldquoIn due course, we hope to make similar improvements to the other side of the boardwalk.

title: tesco-seeks-drop-cash-obligation
story: The company says it no longer owns land ndash the site of its former store at Mall Avenue ndash which is to be turned into  flats by a developer.Tesco has applied to East Lothian Council to mody a contract which was part of an earlier planning consent for residential development at the town centre site, dating back to .The sum of pound, had to be given for extra accommodation at Musselburgh Burgh Primary School and Musselburgh Grammar School.Pritchett Planning Consultancy, on behalf of Tesco Stores Limited, said Tesco now owned and operated the supermarket and petrol filling station at Olivebank Road.It stated: ldquoTesco was previously involved in a land transaction which enabled residential development to be constructed on the site of the former Tesco store site. This transaction took place over a decade ago and the land of the residential development site is not owned by Tesco.ldquoThe section  agreement states that Tesco Stores Limited shall pay an education contribution relating to a residential development on land identied as the third subjects.ldquoTesco has no ownership of the subject site and is not involved in any way in developing the land for residential purposes.The document added: ldquoThis proposed modication to the section  agreement by Tesco seeks to remove Tescorsquos name from the agreement and to replace this with the lsquothird proprietorsrsquo as owners of the residential land on the third subject site.ldquoIn making this change, the agreement would be more aligned with government policy on legal obligations as the agreement would bind the landowner to which the agreement relates rather than a third party which has no involvement in the land or its development.

title: covid-19-testing-centre-returns-former-power-station-site
story: It re-started todayand runs until Wednesday at the site on Edinburgh Road, am-pm.Tests can be booked through the UK Governmentrsquos online system, www.gov.uk get-coronavirus-test, for those who are key workers or those who live with one.Alternatively they can be booked through the NHS website at www.nhs.uk conditions coronavirus-covid-A limited number of home testing kits are available for those who cannot make it to the testing site, but priority will continue to be given to key workers and can be secured by booking through their employer.As of May , testing is for people who have symptoms and are over the age of five as well as household members who are experiencing symptoms.Symptoms include a new continuous cough, a fever and a loss or change in smell or taste.Anyone who develops symptoms is asked to self-isolate immediately as well as all members of their household until they receive a negative test result.More information on testing is available at www.gov.scot publications coronavirus-covid--getting-testedThis is not the first time Covid- testing has taken place at the former power station site.A mobile testing unit first visited the site between May  and  and later visited again from May -June .It was operated by the st Infantry Brigade which oversees the army reserve units in Scotland.

title: shop-owner-thankful-invaluable-support-pandemic
story: Sharon Brown, of Blueberry gt shop, praised the local authorityrsquos prompt response, adding: ldquoThe council was very good to get the money out so quickly.She said: ldquoAs a single person, my only wage comes from the shop so, when it is closed, I have no income but still have to pay bills such as rent and water and sewerage charges.ldquoThe grant from the council allowed me to keep my head above water ndash without it I donrsquot know what I would have done.She stressed that she was glad that her High Street shop was allowed to reopen when it did, as the lockdown was taking its toll on finances and a ldquoworrying time lay ahead.She kept her business going during that time by launching an online shop and making free local deliveries in the EH postcode area to ensure her valued customers still got gts and cards to mark special occasions.Since reopening, Sharon, who also lives in Musselburgh and is secretary of Musselburgh Business Partnership, has been encouraged by the support from the community.She said: ldquoLots of people were glad to see the shop back and I have had lots of positive comments about it.She urged shoppers to continue to support small, independent shops in a bid to keep town centres thriving, with the message ldquouse it or lose it.ldquoIt is important to recognise that small businesses also kept people provided with necessities during the lockdown and stepped into the breach. It proved more than ever how important local, independent businesses are to the area, she added.

title: bid-lodged-shop-cafe-next-car-dealership
story: The John Martin Group has applied for planning permission to carry out alterations and change the use of a showroom and workshop area at the Belmont Group premises on Salters Road.A lsquoto letrsquo sign outside says: ldquoOne ex-car showroom available, surplus to requirements.On plans submitted to East Lothian Council by architects, a chemistrsquos shop is marked as a proposed retail use.It is understood that it will be lsquobusiness as usualrsquo at the adjacent Belmont Wallyford garage and Suzuki car dealership, which is not closing, with no change to the services provided there.The plan for the new development is to utilise an empty building next to the premises.Colin Beattie, MSP for Midlothian North and Musselburgh, said: ldquoWhile I have not seen the details of the proposal, I would, in principle, support the proposed development to provide a pharmacy and cafe restaurant in an otherwise empty premises.ldquoI believe it would provide enhanced services to the community without detracting from the area.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothianrsquos MP, added: ldquoFurther facilities for the community are to be welcomed.ldquoIt is growing fast and outlets are needed.ldquoThe nature of them is for the council to decide but therersquos probably a market for both a cafe restaurant and shop.The Belmont Group is described on its website as ldquoone of Scotlandrsquos best known car dealerships.At Wallyford, the dealership offers new Suzuki models as well as used car brands.The companyrsquos website outlines its history, which stretches back to the s in a lock-up garage in Edinburgh.It states: ldquoFrom these humble origins, the business has grown to become one of Scotlandrsquos leading new and used car dealership groups. On sale are a range of new and used cars from their dealerships, including new Suzuki models.ldquoThe company was founded by John Martin in . Utilising the expertise he gained as a mechanic with a company called Rossleigh in the s, he set up in business on his own in the lsquoLock up down the Lanersquo in Edinburgh.ldquoJohn Martin built his business from the outset on a philosophy of customer care. The business grew.ldquoHe moved from the Lane to a garage, named lsquoBelmontrsquo after an imposing house in the area. John Martin was awarded his first new car franchise, Volvo, in .ldquoThis traded as Murrayfield Motor Company the forerunner of todayrsquos Murray Motor Company.The company went on to gain new franchises at a iety of locations over the years.Belmont at Wallyford made no comment on the planning application when approached by the Courier.

title: nine-10-elcho-green-parking-says-survey
story: East Lothian Council suspended plans to put up to  spaces on Elcho Green, North Berwick, last week ndash as part of efforts to keep people safe from coronavirus ndash met a wave of protests.The local authority pledged to hold a public consultation on its proposals.The SNP Group on the council launched its own survey of local residents to gauge opinion following the outcry and revealed that more than  per cent of those who took part came out against it.In total,  people took part in the survey, which asked: ldquoDo you support the proposals from East Lothian Council relating to the use of Elcho Green as an alternative car parking facility .Councillor Stuart Currie, SNP Group leader, said the overwhelming response was lsquonorsquo.He said: ldquoIt is abundantly clear from the response to this survey, from public conversation, and from the hundreds of emails I have had on this issue that a car park on Elcho Green is not what the people of North Berwick want from the Spaces for People programme.ldquoThe council should now confirm that this will not happen now or in the future.ldquoWhat is clear from the comments is that people understand the need for effective temporary solutions to the combination of tourism and social distancing. There are over  comments and suggestions that have been submitted as part of this survey.ldquoWe will take some time to analyse the comments and we will engage with council officers to ensure these comments are part of the thinking.ldquoThe fact is that the summer period in the North Berwick Coastal area has become a major event in itself.ldquoIn the same way that major events, such as the Open Championship, are planned with groups from the community, councillors, the police, council and many others, it is time for this to happen for this area and that planning should begin in January each year.ldquoWe have produced word clouds of the most common comments from the survey ndash lsquogreenrsquo and lsquospacersquo were the two most common words.ldquoNorth Berwick is a fantastic part of this county and our country ndash for tourism and leisure but it is also a place where people live, and building more and more car parks will only mean more and more cars that no one can cope with.ldquoWhat is now required is a long-term solution that respects residents, helps ensure sustainable tourism and businesses and jobs, but also protects the fragile environment that we are all privileged to enjoy.Kenny MacAskill , East Lothian MP, also welcomed the results of the survey, saying: ldquoI support council colleagues in their work to find a solution to this issue.ldquoAs it is, the proposal is not something I would have supported had I been asked.ldquoItrsquos great to see the level of response from the community.ldquoThis is a council issue, but Irsquom happy to support the community to get to a suitable outcome.A council spokesperson said: ldquoSpaces for People proposals continue to be discussed with a range of stakeholders in our local communities.

title: charity-transport-service-returns-pandemic
story: HcL Transportis running its Dial-A-Ride service again after it was impacted by the coronavirus pandemic.While the service was operational during lockdown, it was limited to urgent medical appointments and funerals.Now, new enhanced cleaning procedures have been introduced both daily and between journeys, with drivers wearing PPE including masks.Passengers must wear masks, unless they have medical reasons to prevent them doing so.A maximum of four passengers from one household can travel at this time, accompanied by a carer.HcL Transport is a local charity that runs transportation services for people with mobility challenges across Edinburgh and the Lothians.Through Dial-A-Ride and Dial-A-Bus services, it helps the elderly, people of any age with disabilities or additional support needs, or those affected by geographic remoteness that makes public transport dficult or impossible to use.For more information, call   .

title: bid-breathe-new-life-historic-church-building
story: Monkscroft Property Limited wants to bring Dunbar Methodist Church back into use, with plans to turn it into a venue for weddings, s and community use.The proposals for a change of use, which have been submitted to East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department, come after the developer bought the Victoria Street building last December.It has sat vacant since the congregations of Dunbar Methodist Church and nearby St Annersquos Scottish Episcopal Church merged in , with the congregation now meeting at the latter.Few changes are proposed for the building, with the developer keen to ldquoensure an important part of the historic fabric of Dunbar can be retained intact for the enjoyment of future generations.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, has already had discussions with the applicants, who live in the town and plan to operate the venue themselves.She was ldquoabsolutely thrilled at the plans for the site and said: ldquoThe sooner it comes back into happy reuse the better for everybody.The community council chairwoman noted that the building was in a prominent position in a recognisable part of the town.She added: ldquoThere were lots of fears ndash it is not a listed building ndash that it would be knocked down and flats built or that it would be knocked down and a house would go up.ldquoThe idea the shell is to be kept and windows restored and used as a wedding venue social venue has been greeted incredibly warmly.A list of benefits for the proposed change of use are included within a supporting statement, which was submitted as part of the planning application.Among the suggested benefits of the scheme are: that it would complement existing hotels and venues by offering a new type of space for small and intimate weddings and other ceremonies that is not currently available in the town it would generate income for local businesses, in particular contributing to the increased use of local hotels and guest houses for short stays in and around Dunbar and it would contribute to ldquothe viability of the town centre.If the plans are given the green light, the developers hope to restore a recognisable aspect of the building.They said: ldquoOne of the first benefits which will flow from planning permission being granted is the restoration of the stained glass windows.ldquoThe restoration will be undertaken at signicant cost by a firm of specialist craftsmen experienced in the restoration of antique ecclesiastical stained glass.It is hoped refurbishment works at the venue could get under way early next year.Dunbarrsquos Methodist Congregation was founded in  and was well established when John Wesley first visited Dunbar in , where he discovered ldquoa little society, most of them rejoicing in God their Saviour.The most celebrated clergyman of his day, Wesley famously founded and led the Protestant Methodist movement in the th century.According to a plaque above the front door, the church was first built in  and was known as the oldest existing Methodist church in Scotland.

title: boost-bid-see-corn-exchange-open-year
story: The venue closed in February last year with an pound, refurbishment planned for the town centre building.Originally, the building was due to open in November last year but that date has twice been pushed back.Firstly, specialist contractors carried out extensive survey work on the building, which dates back to , and found that additional work was required.In February, the local authority said that the target date for reopening was ldquolate summer but the timetable for completion slipped again when the coronavirus pandemic saw renovations at the building put on hold as construction work ground to a halt across the country.Councillor John McMillan, who represents Haddington, gave the good news to the townrsquos community council that a date could be in sight for the workrsquos completion.He stressed the revised date was subject to ldquono other interruptions and said: ldquoI think that is good news.ldquoOriginally, it was to be December but obviously they have been making up time.ldquoObviously, that does not mean it will open in December but it is good to know progress is being made.ldquoWe should not underestimate the pound, investment in that by East Lothian Council. My glass is half full.Three years ago, the local authority set aside the six-figure sum to cover the costs of revamping the building.The work includes the installation of new roof lights, roof repairs and repairing timber flooring in the main hall. New storage areas, additional toilets, a new kitchen and a redecoration of the building are also planned.The venue has held events ranging from art exhibitions and jumble sales to blood donor sessions and concerts featuring the likes of Fish and The Proclaimers.Jan Wilson, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, was pleased to hear progress was being made on the Court Street venue.The building also acts as the headquarters for the Haddington Festival, which was cancelled this year before Covid- struck.Mrs Wilson said: ldquoWeather permitting and whatever Covid throws at us, hopefully it will go ahead and be ready by that time ndash whether it will be let out at all this year, I donrsquot know.ldquoIt will be worth the wait and great to see how it looks and the changes. It has been a great miss because it is such a central place for community events and what not.ldquoWe did not think it was going to be two years without it but things took an unexpected turn with lockdown.ldquoIt would not have been in action evenit had been finished.

title: one-year-no-beer-recognised-government-campaign
story: One Year No Beer was founded by Ruari Fairbairns and helps people tackle their alcohol consumption by offering a toolkit and numbered day challenges to help people survive modern society alcohol free.During lockdown, its staff sacriced their own salaries for three months and it also offered its -day challenge free.Now it is one of  Scottish businesses to be the face of lsquoGREAT Inspirationsrsquo, the UK Governmentrsquos new campaign which celebrates those who have gone above and beyond for their customers, employees or communities by adapting to a new way of working.The campaign was launched on July .More than  companies were selected across the UK for the campaign from a wide range of industries.Ruari said: ldquoOver , people signed up to our free support service and Irsquom just so grateful for the incredibly quick-thinking, open-hearted support and passion that the One Year No Beer team demonstrated during these hard times. This has been such a great opportunity for us to help so many people.lsquoGREAT Inspirationsrsquo is part of the GREAT Britain campaign from the UK Governmentrsquos international marketing campaign to showcase the UKrsquos best and encourage people to visit, study and do business with the UK.More information and a list of all the selected GREAT Inspirations can be viewed at greatbritaincampaign inspirationsFor more information on One Year No Beer, visit oneyearnobeer

title: covid-19-recovery-queen-margaret-universitys-new-plan
story: Professionals educated in many of its key areas, from health sciences to the creative arts and social sciences, have already played key roles in tackling the pandemic.As the university launched its new Strategic Plan, which outlined its goals for the next five years, it was stressed that they would also be ldquovital to the global recovery.Highlighted were the graduates and staff who could already be found in positions all across the world, influencing policy, and enhancing society, culture and the economy. The university aimed to continue ldquoto make a real and immediate dference in the world, in keeping with its values.The strategy described how the university would contribute to societyrsquos ldquorecovery and recalibration following the coronavirus pandemic.It also set out how QMUrsquos ldquoperson-centred approach to learning made it ldquostand out from other universities, along with its ldquodistinctive academic portfolio and a focus on making society better.Through teaching, research and innovation, the university would further develop its work enabling people to ldquoheal, nurture, care and communicate, as well as inspire them to build and rebuild businesses, find solutions to real-le issues and to support communities. It would also build on its track record fostering creativity and artistic expression, building social and economic capital in the process.Sir Paul Grice, principal and vice-chancellor, said: ldquoOur new strategy holds true to the ethos of social justice on which this institution was founded. It sets out how we will nurture and build on our vital work improving society through teaching, research and innovation.

title: city-dwellers-looking-move-east-lothian
story: Since the property market re-opened in Scotland on June , demand for homes in the county has been buoyant, according to Galbraith.In East Lothian, the first property promoted by Galbraith is already under offer, with  families viewing Green Corner at Tyninghame.A signicant percentage of buyers were people relocating from central Edinburgh.Jenner Jeffrey, who heads the Galbraith team for the Lothians, said: ldquoThis demonstrates the strength of the market in East Lothian since the market reopened.ldquoMany of those who viewed the property were leaving Edinburgh city centre to enjoy a better quality of le.ldquoThe experience of being in lockdown has claried for many people that lestyle is the most important criteria when house hunting.ldquoThe advantage of East Lothian is that it is easily commutable but feels a million miles away.ldquoFurthermore, some people may be able to continue to work from home indefinitely from now on, or just go to the office once a week, which opens up the market to a larger pool of buyers.ldquoIn addition to lestyle factors, some people are also considering the price dferential between the city centre and rural areas ndash there is a signicant advantage.Visits to the Galbraith website are up by  per cent since March, as house hunters search for their dream rural home, the property consultancy stated.

title: vandals-target-newly-installed-benches-outside-nursery
story: The wooden benches were put on Dunbarrsquos Abbey Road, outside Cherrytrees Nursery, by Barry Craighead on behalf of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership .However, community councillors in the town noticed that the brackets attaching the benches to the ground were damaged over the weekend.A spokesman for the community council said: ldquoLuckily [there was] no damage to the benches but the retaining brackets are damaged.ldquoIf anyone knows anything about the vandalism attempted theft please let the police know.The damage has since been repaired.

title: water-bottling-plant-expansion-makes-splash
story: Purely Scottish produces mineral water supplies from its factory at Oldhamstocks with water from the nearby Lammermuir Hills.But in a planning application to East Lothian Council, the company said it had seen production fall from sending  lorries to and from the site each week to just six to eight lorries a week.And it said it planned to invest in the plant to bring production back up to its peak and create more jobs.The investment would see an extension built to the plant, the demolition of an older building, and the addition of three ,-litre-capacity water tanks on the site.The planning application for the new extension and water tanks received  objections, with local residents claiming there had been no public consultation over the changes with people living in the village of Oldhamstocks and concerns about the increase in vehicle movements to the plant.However, planning officers ruled that more than enough time was given to residents to respond to the application, which was advertised in the Courier and neighbournotications issued.They said: ldquoAdditionally and in recognition of the dficulties resulting from the Covid- lockdown, the period of time for making representation in respect of the application was extended.East Lammermuir Community Council lodged an objection, calling for limits to times and numbers of HGV trips to the plant, the construction of passing places on the road to the plant from the A, and the establishment of a liaison group between residents and the companyrsquos management to oversee that the conditions were met.East Lothian planners pointed out that the plant had been operating on the site for  years and the extension would secure its long-term future.Planning permission was granted with a number of conditions, including the requirement for a report on actions to reduce carbon emissions from the build and operations to be submitted for approval.

title: love-first-sight-couple-toast-golden-anniversary
story: Norman and Sophia Taylor enjoyed a socially distanced golden wedding anniversary, due to the Covid- restrictions, at their home on North Grange Avenue on July  with their three children.Northumbrian-born Norman, who turned  on June , met Sophia, , in Prestonpans Royal British Legion in , saying it was ldquolove at first sight and ldquoeyes over a dance floor.The pair married shortly afterwards at Prestonpans Register Office and then went on to travel the world due to Normanrsquos job as a fitter and turner, a trade he learned in the Merchant Navy.The family travelled across Britain between  and . They then stayed in Africa between  and , including Zambia, with the children attending public school in South Africa.However, Sophia started to feel homesick so moved back to Prestonpans in .Norman then got a job in Libya, working four weeks away and then being back at home for four weeks. He worked in this job for the rest of his career, retiring  years ago.During his working le, Norman was also a delivery driver.However, after his retirement he took on the role as a golf caddy at Muirfield, near Gullane.Prestonpans-born Sophia, as Cissie to her friends, worked as a barmaid, including at the former Lady Susan pub in Prestonpans.When Norman married Sophia, she had three children from a previous marriage: Richard, now aged , Charles, , and Eileen, .Their grandson Kal, described as the ldquoapple of their eye, was born in  and was ldquospoiled rotten according to Sophia.Norman and Sophia have sadly been in poor health recently, with Norman suffering a heart attack this year.However, he still makes an effort to visit the Legion in Prestonpans twice a week, every Monday and Friday.When the Legionrsquos beer garden re-opened and Norman was able to go back to his favourite bar, Richard said it was ldquothe first time I have seen a smile on his face for months.Norman says the secret to a long marriage is ldquothe we is always right.Richard added: ldquoThey are totally in love. Irsquove never seen my mum and dad fight and my dad has never risen his voice once. My dad is an absolute gentleman and they absolutely dote on each other.

title: inner-wheel-walkers-raise-hundreds-charity
story: The women set off from Haddington on the .-mile railway walk to Longniddry on Sunday at .pm.Ninety minutes later, they reached their destination.It not yet known how much has been raised, with hopes it could be about pound.Grants can then be given to local good causes who get in touch with the Inner Wheel Club of Tranent.A spokeswoman for the group said: ldquoWe would like to thank everybody for their kind donations, which will benefit local charities.

title: rnli-coastguard-crews-called-three-times-two-hours
story: With people heading to East Lothians beaches, the volunteer crews were called out between pm and pm.The most serious incident came at about pm after reports that someone had fallen from a clf at Gin Head, to the east of the town.RNLI and Coastguard volunteers were alerted, with Coastguard colleagues from Fisherrow and Dunbar also called out alongside a rescue helicopter.As North Berwick Coastguard arrived on scene, its members found the casualty at the bottom of the clfs.They treated the inidual, where their injuries were found to not be le-threatening, and, with support, they were helped up the clf to an awaiting ambulance.The leboat crew, which was called at pm, was stood down at the scene as North Berwick Coastguard had traced the casualty and had been able to recover them.The first call out of the day had come at about pm after reports of a missing child on the beach.However, the call was very quickly cancelled as the child had been traced.An hour later, the crew was then paged to recover a capsized dinghy off Milsey Bay.The inidual in the dinghy, its only occupant, had already been brought to shore by the time the leboat crew arrived.Thankfully, the inidual emerged unharmed and the leboat crew retrieved the dinghy and a crew member sailed it back to shore.It marked the start of a busy weekend for the volunteer crews.On Saturday, at .am, North Berwick Coastguard was called to Longniddry to reports of two people in the water following a capsized dinghy.Fisherrow Coastguard and Kinghorn RNLI, from Fe, were also called.After crews arrived on scene, it turned out it was not a dinghy but a kite surfer who had been assisted by fellow kite surfers to safety.The call was described as a  alarm with good intent.Shortly after pm, the Coastguard team was called to Eyemouth to assist its local coastguard crew with a medical evacuation, however the crew was stood down on route as the inidual concerned had been recovered.A spokesperson for North Berwick title: schools-celebrate-success
story: Exams may have been cancelled for the first time in nearly  years in Scotland but youngsters were awarded grades based on assessments by their teachers of their work and progress which was reviewed by the SQA.And in East Lothian the hard work paid off with Maths and English pass rates increased on last year and  per cent of sixth year students receiving pass rates - the highest figure in five years.The number of young people in East Lothian achieving A-C grades in Higher qualications also increased to  per cent - up five per cent on last year.More S students presented for Highers and the pass rate went up to  per cent - two per cent higher than last year.Across all year groups for Higher English the pass rate was up by % to % and in Maths, which had been an area of focus, it was up from  per cent ot  per cent.In total , candidates in East Lothian received , awards.At National  level  per cent of those presented achived A-C grades and just over a third recevied an A.The pass rate for National  English remained steady at  per cent and those receiving an A increased from  per cent to  per cent on the previous year.In Maths the national  pass rate went from  per cent to  per cent.The number of S pupils achieving five or more awards at National  or better decreased by three per cent to  per cent.The number of students taking Advanced Highers in S fell to  per cent this year.The percentage of all students passing Advanced Higher increased by five per cent to . per cent and pass rates at A Grades were at their highest level with  per cent.Lesley Brown, the councils chief operating officer for education, said: ldquoThis yearrsquos exam results show improvements across a range of qualication levels."I am particularly pleased to see the results of our focus on improving Maths, evidenced in the results at National  and Higher."Our schools will continue to build on this positive picture in the new academic year. I am also delighted with the five per cent increase in pupils achieving A-C grade at Higher level.ldquoThe cancellation of the exam diet for this year was challenging for our pupils and our staff."Irsquod like to commend everyone on the resilience that they showed and congratulate all of our learners on their achievements."Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet member for education, said: ldquoCongratulations to all our young people on the success they have achieved in their SQA results. The results show improvements in Maths and English across all levels which is welcome news."The last few months have been a very stressful and challenging time for young people, their families and school staff.ldquoThanks must go to our young people for all their hard work and effort over the past year and to their parents and carers who have supported them.
