title: vaughan gething visits penarth club recognise lockdown efforts
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityMr Gething, whose son regularly attended football training in the junior section at the football club tied to the social club prior to the pandemic, stopped by to talk about the challenges that will face the club in the near future as a result of Covid-, and members explained how they have used the closure to make an even better go of le after lockdown.Dean Ford, a committee member at the club, who initially contacted Mr Gething to help mark the reopening, spoke about le during lockdown, and the challenges ahead.ldquoItrsquos been a really dficult and worrying time, and there is little doubt wersquod have closed without the support of the business grant we received, he said.The social clubis home to more than  junior footballers alone, making it the biggest footballing institution in the Vale.Dean Ford and Lee WilliamsIt is also now home to the only pub in Cogan, following the closure of The Station during lockdown.Close friends with tenants Natasha and Gareth, Mr Fordand fellow committee member Lee Williams said it compounded their concerns for the industry.ldquoItrsquos a real shame because theyrsquore great people and we were always in there, Mr Ford said. ldquoItrsquos a worrying time for pubs, but wersquove got through the worst of it hopefully, thanks I think to how cautious the Welsh Government has been."Over the past ten weeks, a group of eight volunteers have teamed up to refurbish the social club ready for Monday and beyond.The club was busy on Monday after the club asked for support on social medialdquoWe had no beer garden and all our events were cancelled, so we really would have been closed for good without the grant we received, said Mr Williams.ldquoThe only people that have been in here since March are the maintenance guys, and theyrsquove done a great job. Wersquove also really tried to push the reopening on social media and it seems to have worked.A few new faces were in on Monday afternoon, while some older friends ed to support the club too.ldquoItrsquos brilliant to see and is something we really need at the moment, Mr Williams added.Vaughan Gething speaking with membersAs a trial, the club will be opening from pm Monday to Thursday, and will continue operating from pm on Fridays and weekends.On Vaughan Gething visiting the club, Mr Ford added: ldquoItrsquos nice to have the recognition and for him to recognise wersquove suffered. Itrsquos so important for the message to support local businesses.On the challenges of social distancing and avoiding new cases after lockdown, Mr Ford said: ldquoItrsquos dficult but wersquove done everything we can in terms of people signing in, not standing at the bar, wersquove implemented a one-way system.       ,params: .pushldquoHopefully things will get a bit more relaxed soon. It feels like Wales is in the best place to start doing that.Mr Gething said it had been ldquoreally dficult to see the club struggle and praised them for their resilience.ldquoThe refurb here is fantastic and I felt it was so important to come here and recognise the work that has been put in, he said.ldquoFor the sake of clubs like this, it is so important people follow the guidance to avoid a repeat of lockdown, which could be really dficult for businesses to respond to.ldquoI appreciate itrsquos dficult because these are social environments, but I would urge caution ndash especially come the autumn and winter when we expect new cases may occur.ldquoIrsquom confident the test and trace process will improve and work to mitigate those concerns, and ensure we donrsquot see what wersquore now seeing in places like Australia and Spain. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log        ,params: .push-- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... introduced additional health and safety measures with the wellbeing of visitors and staff at the heart.The multitude of measures came as venues inside the complex reopened to the public on Monday, August .Venue managers, Savills Management Resources have worked collaboratively with the Centrersquos leisure and dining occupants, to implement the safety measures in accordance with Welsh government guidelines to reopen safely this week.MORE STORIESBarry balloon artist Doctor Bob goes wild at Cardf Bays Red Dragon CentreBobs balloon creations set to wow thousands at extravaganzaJames arrows indicate the direction of travel in the new system, supplemented by a iety of audio and visual reminders including public address system announcements, rope and pole barrier systems, and branded, bilingual signage stationed at each entrance.Venues at The Red Dragon Centre will also be implementing queuing systems to monitor capacity and maintain social distancing within their inidual outlets and in accordance with their risk assessments.Venues including Cadwaladers and Cardf Bay Tavern have reopened their indoor dining facilities, while leisure venues Hollywood Bowl will open on Tuesday, August  and Simply Gym will open on Monday, August .Restaurants Zaika and Five Guys, who have been operating takeaway and delivery services during lockdown, also reopen for indoor dining, with Five Guys joining Cadwaladers and Cardf Bay Tavern in participating in the UK Governmentrsquos lsquoEat Out to Help Out lsquoscheme on Mondays through to Wednesdays.Cadwaladers store manager, Bernadette Cammilleri said: ldquoWe are delighted to welcome customers back to our cafeacute for indoor dining.ldquoWersquove been working closely with the Centre on a range of measures to ensure customers feel safe and enjoy their experience when they decide to visit.To mitigate the spread of covid- throughout the Centre, cashless payment systems are in place where possible and an enhanced cleaning regime has been introduced with special attention being paid to touchpoints.Procedures such as the use of PPE when necessary, hygiene protocols such as frequent handwashing and cleaning in a way which is anti-microbially effective have also been recommended to staff.Red Dragon Centre manager, Clare Jenkins said: ldquoWe are thrilled to be able to welcome visitors back to the Centre and have worked hard to ldquo#bringbackthefunsafely.ldquoSafety is at the heart of our reopening plans.ldquoWe have drawn on the expertise within Savills and collaborated with each brand inidually to ensure, in accordance with Welsh government guidelines, that both staff and customers are able to enjoy their experience at the Centre.ldquoIt is important that we try to keep everyone safe as we title: local radio station announces plans launch penarth

title: changes made penarth town centre lockdown plans
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAs reported in the Penarth Times on Thursday, the town councilsaid the results show ldquowidespread backing for changes.The survey, which attracted  responses, showed  per cent of people thought there should be more outdoor space for pedestrians and businesses.Seventy-five per cent thought parking arrangements needed to change, and  per cent said the town needs to ldquoprepare for the future.Some traders, who oppose the changes ndash specically a one-way traffic system around the town and making Windsor Road and Lower Glebe Street a traffic free zone, have said the questions in the survey were too generalised and misleading.As a result of the survey, Penarth Town Council have proposed the following changes to the original ideas:Windsor Road from Arcot Street to the roundabout as a ldquoshared space for delivery vehicles and buses, with a mph speed limit.Lower Glebe Street as a ldquoshared space for delivery vehicles and disabled bays. Other vehicles should not use Lower Glebe Street as a through road.Bus stops will remain as they are. There were concerns over the impact of a bus stop on Hickman Road for traders, due to air pollution, noise pollution and congestion.A two-way system to remain on Stanwell Road from the library to the traffic lights, to allow easy access to the bus stop on Rectory Road and to prevent congestion and ldquorat running through Hickman Road and Arcot Street. A two-way system to also remain from Windsor Road to Railway Terrace.The number of parking bays has also changed. There will now be  extra bays proposed, with  of them on Plassey Street.The leader of the town council, Cllr Rhiannon Birch, explained the findings and what happens next.ldquoEven before Covid-, town centres across the country were facing issues, including the need to modernise infrastructure, and the impact of online shopping, she said. ldquoThe current pandemic has added to the scale of the challenge.ldquoThe consultation shows that a clear majority recognise the need for a degree of change in the town centre, both for it to survive in the present and to thrive in future.ldquoThe results call for the establishment of a greater degree of safe space and proposals which increase a degree of pedestrianisation whilst also increasing parking spaces.ldquoThe results show substantial agreement on these aims. Reflecting this widespread and clear response, Penarth Town Council calls on our partners in the Vale of Glamorgan Council to embrace the results and recommendations.ldquoSpecically, Penarth Town Council believes that creating a safer environment through the closure of Windsor Road to traffic for part of the day, between Arcot Street and the roundabout, including the Lower Glebe Street, would be the best way to ensure that people can feel confident about shopping safely. It would allow safe use of the space in front of shops, bars, cafes and restaurants.ldquoIt also lessens the need for one-way systems on pavements for pedestrians, which are perplexing for many and hard to implement. These proposals can be achieved in a way which also increases the amount of parking spaces available.The results will now be put to the Vales Planning Committee for consultation.For more information, visit https:www.penarthtowncouncil.gov.uk news survey-results Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: autumn date set opening new south lake leisure centre
story: Stolen car used in ram-raid attack on shopRestaurant which provides employment for young people with special needs closes its doorsNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleAutumn date set for opening of new South Lake Leisure CentreA date has been set for the opening of the new south lake leisure centre in Craigavon with the multi-million-pound facility to open its doors on November .By The NewsroomTuesday, th July , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th July , : pm""The largest capital project to date undertaken by ABC Council, and among the largest in Northern Ireland, the new multi-use sports and leisure complex is described by the council as a major new flagship health and wellbeing destination.Work on the facility was halted by the coronavirus outbreak. Since ing to site Farrans, the contractor in charge of the build, has ensured the contract is completed ready for opening in the Autumn.Farrans has been spearheading the build since initial enabling works got under way early in , creating  jobs on site during construction as part of a project which has delivered at least £. million in direct wages to the local economy.Located at the south side of Craigavon’s balancing lake, the facility is a landmark venue for the area and is situated within a pre-existing network of walking and cycling paths covering around three miles. The council hopes the new leisure centre will welcome visitors from across the borough and beyond to its new -metre pool, a young children’s indoor leisure water feature, a ,m state-of-the-art gym, multiple studios, health and wellbeing suite, sensory room, eight-court sports halls, spin studio, soft play area and an on-site café.It also incorporates an outdoor water sports provision offering a wide range of water based activities including windsurfing, water skiing and paddle sports. The council says the scale of South Lake Leisure Centre has been future-proofed to meet the needs of a growing population and a raising demand from a range of leisure, amateur and professional sporting enthusiasts.Lord Mayor of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon, Councillor Kevin Savage, sai: “With a confirmed opening date just  weeks away, I am delighted that this stunning new centre - which will have fabulous facilities for everyone in the borough to access and enjoy - is almost complete.“South Lake Leisure Centre provides a once-in-a-generation opportunity to transform and dramatically enhance the quality of health and leisure provision within the borough, providing community access for everyone to the best facilities available in the UK and Ireland.”As part of the preparations for the official opening of South Lake Leisure Centre, interim arrangements have been agreed for leisure facilities in Portadownand Brownlow . Cascades Leisure Complex will be open to the public for lane swimming only in August, remaining open until Saturday th October.Craigavon Leisure Centre will remain open to the public for gym only until Monday th October. Waves Leisure Complex will be closed to the public.When all these facilities, which are approaching the end of their al le close, leisure staff will begin their training at the new South Lake Leisure Centre building.""Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us onExploreNewsSportWhats OnLestyleMore from Portadown TimesAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoDirectoryLocal GuideReader ShopUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessAdvertise a JobPlace your AdSubscribeEventsArchiveReaders Charter" fill"#ea"©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-gxMtzJ sc-dfVpRl dLpuYr"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policyNews you can trust since News" class"expand" role"button" tabindex""""" scale translate " points"  .  . title: new store and  jobs pipeline
story: Stolen car used in ram-raid attack on shop‘Discouragement’ after man charged with indecent abuse of DUP’s Arlene Foster escapes with cautionNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPoliticsNew store and  jobs in pipelineA major new chain store is on its way to Lurgan and could bring  jobs to the town, a local councillor has said.By The NewsroomFriday, th August , : pmUpdated Friday, th August , : pm""The application, lodged by applicant Inaltus Ltd on behalf of Curly Properties Ltd is for a retail development with car parking, landscaping, access and associated site works developed atvacant lands north of Millennium Way, Lurgan.Originally submitted in  the planning proposal has been recommended for approval by Council’s planning officers and will,approved, see Home Bargains arrive in town.Speaking in support of the application, Councillor Joe Nelson said it would bring “signicant economic benefits… including some  new jobs” to Lurgan.“I believe the site location is ideal for this development as it provides adequate car parking in situ and is located on Millenium Way which is in fact the relief road for Lurgan Town Centre,” say the SDLP councillor.“Bringing this development to the town while keeping the town centre free from extra congestion is the ideal position.“I strongly support these proposals and trust that the material considerations, associated with the economic and other benefits of the scheme, will be considered in detail by the Council planners.”Upper Bann MLA Jonathan Buckley has expressed “strong support” for the application.“The proposals will see the delivery of a Home Bargains store for Lurgan along with signicant economic benefits including a multi-million pound investment into the local economy and the creation of some  new jobs,” said the DUP MLA“At a time when many people are losing their jobs and many businesses are having to close, proposal such as this, where successful major retailingbusinesses are willing to commit to Lurgan, the Council must give very serious consideration to these proposals.”However, an independentreview of the application by Tom Stokes Associated Planning expressed concerns that rather than support the town centre, the application,approved, is “more likely to create an alternative retail destination to the town centre”.The report said that with  per cent of the Lurgan town centre’s turnover allocated to just two stores, the remaining smaller conveniencestores in Lurgan could be “vulnerable to impact” by the approval of this application.The review also suggested that the proposal would be better suited to the former Tesco site in Castle Lane as it is “a key regeneration site in the town centre”.However, in response to this, the application’s agent, Inaltus Ltd, said: “If this site did not suit Tesco’s servicing requirements, there are no grounds for TSA to suggest it will suit Home Bargains.”In conclusion Inaltus Ltd’s response to TSA assessmentstates that whilst some aspects of the TSA Review can be agreed “other aspects are illogical and do not form a sound basis to refuse the proposal on”.It also notes that no objections have been lodged in over  months and called for the application to be brought before Council’s planning committee.The application is now set to appear before Wednesday’smeeting of the planning committee, with officer’s recommending that the application is approved.-------A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website.
